Preece was the Government electrical engineer; he was the head of the Post Office, the technical part of it, for many years; you could not possibly have obtained the co-operation of a better man, not one known better—you and I met him many, many times—Thomas Parker is of Wolverhampton and London; he is probably one of the most eminent engineers in the construction of railways and tramways; he acts for the Metropolitan District, I believe, or the Metropolitan Railway Company—at the time we formed this company there was a very large project which we hoped to be engaged in through Thomas Parker and Mr. Macrae, the electrification of the Metropolitan Railway—I remember going to break
fast many times at Mr. Maerae's—Mr. Parker was acting for the Metro
politan Railway—I do not remember that Mr. Parker was selected as the arbiter in the dispute between the Metropolitan District and the Metro
politan; I know he had a great deal to do with it—I do not think that men of that sort would all join together with us for a mere device, to put money into your pocket—Mr. Macrae at that time when we were form
ing this Street Company was himself in daily consultation as far as we knew with the Metropolitan Railway for a great scheme in connection with this electrification—I have not seen you since the last Police Court proceedings—if Mr. Macrae and Mr. Thomas Parker, Sir W. Preece and Major Cardew had brought about the project that they were then engaged upon, the Street Company ought to have been a very rich com
pany to-day—I was chairman—the idea was that, instead of the electrifica
tion being done in America, as it is now being done, it was to be done in London, under Thomas Parker, our engineer; under the Ganz system, which would have brought us lots of money; that was the expensive arbitration that was curried out afterwards between the Metropolitan Railway Company and the District Railway Company, about two years ago, to settle which system was to be adopted, and Mr. Parker lost it; if he had won thousands of men would to-day be employed on this very project—I should have had nothing to do with you if I had had any suspicion that it was a mere device for putting money into your pocket—the solicitors of the Street Company were Messrs. Lumley & Lumley; the directors left to them the drawing up of the papers; Mr. Harper, one of the partners, acted—they took counsel's opinion on everything, and they were very, very particular about it—a very respectable firm of brokers was employed and put on the prospectus, well-known stockbrokers, bur I had "Forgotten that—as chairman I allowed this prospectus to be used, and on it it says that sufficient working capital had already been guaranteed: I "Understood that was the case, and that is why we knew, before the company went to allotment, that it would certainly go to allotment: the working capital was guaranteed—I believe that the profit which we made was all paper, all shares—I think that the inventions of Thomas Parker, electrician and electrical engineer of the Metropolitan Railway, would be likely to prove of value—Thomas Parker, of Wolver
hampton, is paying large regular dividends, and he has a very prosperous company indeed: the Elwell Parker Company it is called—that was founded by him, and he was engineer to it at this time—I think he was engaged at that time in bringing out an altogether new system of electrical

traction, which was put in our prospectus—I gather that I went down to Wolverhampton; I have been to the Wolverharnpton works several times, but whether I went down on that occasion I do not remember—knowing him to be what he was, and knowing that his works in Wolverhampton and his business paid so uncommonly well (it states on the front page of the prospectus what the dividend was), we were perfectly justified in believing that we had got a good thing—I do not remember if the Mid
land Syndicate was one of Thomas Parker's syndicates—we made all our paper, or most of it, our shares that we had to take for profit in the flotation of this Street Company, all deferred scrip—that was the sugges
tion of Mr. Macrae, who was the proprietor of the "Financial Times"; lie subscribed, or underwrote, £10,000 in the company—he came out on morning with an article in which he put this scheme at full length in the "Financial Times," the ordinary shares being made deferred shares, so as to give subscribers an advantage over our paper that we had to take as our paper profit—the Construction Company had to take this paper profit, and we willingly stood behind and let the public come in first if there was any dividend—there is nothing very fraudulent in that—the company had a half share in the Walthamstow Railway: that was the arrangement made—I was chairman of the promoters of the Walthamstow Railway, therefore I knew every single thing about it—we started this work of running this Bill in Parliament, and with the money we got from the Street Company the Construction-Company began to run this Bill—the Walthamstow Railway was the most beneficent scheme and project that could possibly be suggested for Bethnal Green and East London, owing to the overcrowded condition of the population there; it was part of our idea that we should have halfpenny electric fares for the poor people, to take them right out into the country, where they could get cheap dwellings; of the various Bills that were being promoted at the rime it was well known that the City and North East Suburban Railway was the pick of them all—I, with the other gentlemen whose names were in the Bill, signed a small trust deed by which the Bill was the property of the Construction Company, and the Construction Company agreed with the Street Company that half of it belonged to them: that is my recol
lection—Mr. Walter Webb drew it—the original, if I remember, was with Messrs. Walter Webb & Company, and it would be a copy with the Con
struction Company—the Street Company put in £2,700 towards the pro
motion of the Bill—our expenses would not come to £5,000 in January, 1901—nobody else had any interest in it but us until a long time after
wards—Mr. Wack put £1,000 in; that must have been in 1902; I cannot recollect if by that time our two companies had paid Mr. Webb alone about £17,500; I know there was a great deal of money paid over to him—my recollection is that we had paid for costs in this Bill at the time 1'ierpoint Morgan came in, two years afterwards, well over £20.000—I believe up to the time that Morgans came in others had found
funds for The promotion, other than the Construction Company, the Street Company, and the Founders' Syndicate—I recollect this American, Mr. Wack—two or three others came in; Mr. Webb brought in several people to help—I think there was somebody else who put money in; I cannot recollect

who it was; those other persons did not put so much money in as Mr. Week: I remember Mr. Webb said he had found somebody to put some more money in—my recollection is that the Construction Company and the Street Company practically owned this Bill proportionately between them; that is also with the Street Company including the Founders' Syndicate: they were part owners too—this is a copy of the bill: it say: The Company incorporated; Sir James Kenneth Douglas Mackenzie, Bart., of Tar bat, Henry William Tigwell, Nathaniel Fortesque, Edward Thomas Heed, and Gerald Ward Martin: those were the original pro
moters of the Bill—a trust deed was signed saving that you were the owners of the Bill; whether all signed it or not I do not know, but at any rate the necessary quorum signed it: I recollect the deed quite well—the proposed capitalization was over three millions—I do not recollect what Sir Douglas Fox swore before the House of Lords what the profit would be; it is a big sum of money; 10 per cent., I think, would be allowable on a matter of that nature; it would be a most moderate profit—10 per cent, on the cost of construction in this case would have been at any rate £'500,000—I think it was, 3 1/2 millions for building the line—if there is an excessive profit the Bill is thrown out; it is one of the objections to it—in this case we should have had over £'500,000 profit", probably—I think Sir Clinton Dawkins stood up in that Committee and gave evidence that he would find over two millions of the money—he represented J.S. Morgan k Co.; it was really a guaranteed undertaking—I know Walter Webb's signature—(letter read): "To Charles Osborne, secretary. Electric Tramways Construction and Main
tenance Company, Limited, "54, Victoria Street. Dear Sir. City and North East Suburban Electric Railway. We enclose you the estimate lodged on the 31st ult. As you know, the deposit has to be made on the 13th inst., namely 3 per cent, on £-1,950,000, that is £97,300 has to be paid as a deposit in respect of Bill Xo.1"; we had two bills; there was another one brought in afterwards;"3 per cent, on the second Bill, namely, on £966,202, being £48,.'511, total deposit £143,811"—that was the total deposit we had to lodge in cash in the Bank of England; and we did it; I was one of the signatories—"The Alliance Insurance Company, as we have informed you, have agreed to advance the amount upon the same terms as last year ": we had been through it all once before: "namely 2 per cent, and the usual brokerage. Tin's will amount to a little over £'5.000, which you will let us have in due time. We enclose you two more copies of the hand map ": as a matter of fact, with the brokerage it cost us nearly £3,000 each time simply for the loan of the money—I do not recollect if I went with you and saw Mr. Pierpoint Morgan's private solicitor in New Inn: Mr. Webb saw the City. Morgan's solicitor, the City house—this railway would have given us a profit of £00,000; we should have had no difficulty afterwards with Morgan's guarantee: we could get the rest, because it would be debentures—we came up at two Sessions for certain, and then it was referred to a Joint Committee of both Houses of Parliament: that Taint Committee had all the tube railways in London brought before it, and after much cross-examination and any amount of hard work day and night, they threw out the majority of the railways

except ours—I do not remember if the Lord Mayor of London, the Bishop of London, and the Corporation of the City of London all sup
ported our view; it had very great support: I do not remember who sup
ported it—we all felt and expressed the opinion that it was almost an iniquity that this railway was thrown out, because it would have relieved the whole of those ten people in the room business in Bethnal Green; it was more the Great Eastern Railway and the North London Railway, who admitted at the time they were unable to cope with the traffic, and we afterwards bad their support; of course it was not really a tube railway; if was only a tube for a short service, then it became an ordinary electric railway; that was why it was to be built cheaply—if we had succeeded the British Electric Street Company shareholders would have had a good dividend; they would have had about £150,000 profit, and I should say (he Construction Company would have had £l. 0,000 profit, probably, and this prosecution would hardly have taken place—I believe that this railway belonged to the company and to the British Street Company; I believe the two companies were jointly interested in the concern—the books only show about £2,700 paid by the Street Company—the money did not come from Mr. Webb—when the company had not got any money you constantly put up your own cheque for £1,000, and Mr. Webb has had dozens of your cheques—I did not know any of the details of the Construction Company until a day before the dinner; of course I heard of it ever since I met you—the letters show that I wrote to you asking that I might have an interest in the great tramway scheme at Blackpool—I went down with you and Mr. Osboroe to Blackpool: I remember riding on the top of the old-fashioned gas tramway with you and Mr. Osborne—I do not recollect that we had our photographs taken on the top—this was when the Construction Company was buying up the shares, or you were buying up the shares for the Construction Company, and the Construction Can any was beginning to find money to maintain the gas tramway—it was run, I believe, by the Construction Company for some time prior to our taking it over for the Blackpool South—I never attended any Board meetings in Blackpool of the old tramway—I believe the Blackpool Company Travel got the new tramway—I do not remember the details of what they have, but I know dividends were paid to them—I signed a lot of dividend warrants for the Blackpool Company; I do not remember what they were—for a little time I was director of the new Blackpool South Company—it was a very respectable, good, sound, solid company, with plenty of money in it—it was brought out by you and the Construction Company; I was not on it when it was brought out, but soon afterwards—I do not know if anybody but you and the Construction Company and the underwriters ever brought out or promoted this Blackpool Com
pany—Mr. Hunter was the dominant power in the Construction Company at that time; he was a very active director, and did most of everything; he was really chairman of the company, and that is why I wrote to him that, letter which was read; it is a most unfortunate thing for us that he is dead and unable to be present—I do not know that no shareholder has given up a shilling, and float the capital of the Blackpool Company has not been reduced with the exception that all the unissued shares, and

those that the Construction Company took up, those that we had coming to us fully-paid paper, had been written off—I relied to a certain extent on what Mr. Hunter told me—I do not remember that we ever issued to the public any document of any sort or kind with my name as chair
man unless it was. In connection with some of the Nottingham Bills, but there were no circulars sent round except the dinner invitation; no appli
cation to the public that I know of—it never has been offered to the pubic; it has never been floated or brought out in the ordinary way—relieve has never been any public money subscribed to my knowledge in the Construction Company for shares: I have always believed the Con
struction Company was a private concern altogether—when I first saw you the subscribed working capital of the Construction Company had been sup
plied solely by you: Colonel Harris put £2.10 in, but you have done all the work of the Construction Company—my name was never used publicly and there are no public in it—I never knew you to be in a fiduciary rela
tion to the Board, acting under the instructions of the Board and acting as a paid manager you were never a servant nor a paid manager—you worked these schemes up and brought them to the Construction Com
pany, and made proposals and propositions to take them over—I know that you are a member of the Institute of Mechanical Engineers, and would be fairly entitled to charge the Construction Company and send in an account for any work you did, although it is like charging yourself, in one way; still, for the purpose of formal, regular order and book keeping, there ought to be some record—I do not know of any creditors of the Construction Company—as a professional engineer you are entitled to send in a bill in the ordinary way—if I brought you a proposition, with £100,000 capital, it would be perfectly lawful that you should have a share for the introduction of the business—I suppose almost half the City make their livelihood out of commissions for the introduction of business—I should charge as much as I could get from you for commission, but I should say at any rate 10 per cent.; that would be 10 per cent, on £100,000—I consider, as a civil engineer, that a man is lawfully entitled, and has a lawful right, to charge a syndicate or a company £10,000 for introducing a £100,000 project or scheme, if it is a good business; of course it is not an engineer's fees, an engineer does not make 10 per cent.: but it is commonly paid, and if they agree to it that is sufficient; it may not be payable in cash, if it is a success it would be—if the com
pany take it over it is a common practice to say: "If you adopt my scheme I shall want so much down in cash and the balance when it goes through, "otherwise you would be tying it up, and would get nothing for it and perhaps lose the scheme for nothing—you had a right to do the same thing with the Construction Company—usually, with a £100,000 scheme, company promoters would make about 25 per cent, profit; you would not get anybody in the City to take it up unless it shows about 25 per cent, profit—we should expect the man who brought it to us was honestly entitled to at least £10,000 out of it, especially If he had devoted time and given work to it: a mere commission agent would not get that—if you had sent an account at that time on to the Electric Tramways Company, properly made out on the rate I have said, you

would have been entitled to have received a very-large sum of money, much larger than anything they have ever paid you—the Blackpool shares were selling at that time at a good price, and the company had made over £100,000—that is my recollection—therefore you were entitled to a good share of that profit—if you had not held 50,000 shares you would have wanted to have been paid, and if they had not paid you, and you had sued them in the ordinary way, you would have got it—I suppose you introduced Thomas Parker to the company; nobody else, to my knowledge introduced the Street Car Company of Wolverhampton—you would do entitled to charge for many interviews and negotiations in going down to Wolverhampton, paying the railway fare out of your own pocket, staying in the hotel, and seeing all the different people in the Car Com
pany, and for introducing buyers of shares of the Street Company—if you sold 20,000 shares you would be entitled to charge a commission—you would be entitled to charge for introducing the Exeter Tramways, and for interviews, hotel and travelling expenses to Exeter, and living there for a week, introducing and negotiating the formation of the new Exeter Tramways, and attending town councillors' meetings in Exeter—I saw the town clerk and the council men—you would be entitled to charge for arranging with local authorities, selecting the route, surveying, meeting landowners, engineers, Parliamentary agents, solicitors, commis
sions paid, all those sort of things—I cannot answer yes or no as to 10 per cent, on the introduction of the scheme or project: that would naturally depend upon their amount—whatever the out-of-pocket expenses came to you would be entitled to charge a fair price for—the Electric Tramway Construction Company was not sham two years ago—it is not true to say that it never had a penny, that it has not a penny, that it never could have a penny, and that I never will have a penny—I know Mr. Cotterel, the engineer; his valuation as to what this Blackpool recon
struction was to cost was greatly in excess of what Mr. Nevins estimated—I met Mr. Nevins; he was an Irishman and a very jolly fellow; he had a great experience of tramway building; he was a well-known man in New York, and had a large business there—we were not obliged to be bound by Cotterell's estimate—if we could build it any cheaper so much the better for us, and all the profit over the actual cost of building the tramway, and the £5,000 working capital, and the obtaining of the old company would belong to the Construction Company, if that were the terms of the arrangement—I do not know if at the time of the dinner no balance-sheet had been got out; I never saw one—when I was discussing as to what the announcement, was I was going to make at the dinner I wasn't basing my estimate upon any figures in a balance-sheet—you told me that you were going to declare a dividend of 12 per cent., and that you would be glad if I would do it for you; you were responsible if it was based upon only an estimate that we had heaps of money—I suppose Hunter and the other directors who talked of the matter were estimating that we had plenty of money—to pay 12 per cent, would cost about £6,000 on the capital—when I stood up at that-dinner I said there was close upon £1 Of),000 capital, and the vouchers for that sum I had seen, or approximately that sum—they were shown to me—I have a recollection

of seeing two bankers' slips, but I cannot remember the exact amount in them—I know the contention of the prosecution is that I made a statement which was fraudulently misleading when I said "close upon £100,000"; but it is four-fifths, £1,000, just over four-fifths—it is quite enough to have paid the dividend, which is all I had to look to—I cannot see any
thing materially misleading in using the words close upon £100,000—£70,000 was the only amount we had to pay Nevins for constructing the line, and that left £11,000 and some shares, therefore £81,000 left a margin of £11,000; so that even if no more money had come in there was enough to have paid the dividend—the application form says: "I undertake to pay up the rest of the subscriptions"—I was not leading people to believe that we had a great deal more money than we really had; I was not leading them astray—I never said there was £100,000 free cash—I understood at the time what money was there was free to be dealt with, and certainly £6,000 could he had, and it did not state when the dividend would be paid—there is no statement in the speech that it would be paid this week or next—at the police court I said it was avail
able for the purposes of the company, but one of the purposes of the company was building the tramway, therefore the whole £100,000 would be available for the purposes of the company, and for the payment of the dividend only £6,000 was wanted—we considered we were entitled to draw on the money that came in from the Blackpool Company, because all the shares and debentures we were selling belonged to us, and we had them in our office—I have a recollection of hour saving that you had money, cash in hand at any rate available: I do not recollect whether you said it came from the Blackpool subscriptions—I have a recollection of a meet
ing having been called at the Cannon Street Hotel, but when I do not remember; it must have been after the dinner, because the dinner was so soon after I came to the company—I do not recollect that you had found out that Mr. Rutherford had never been authorised by the Black
pool Trams to insist upon an agreement being drawn between you and Rutherford and the directors of the Construction Company—I do not remember anything of the meeting—this agreement was entirely set aside, and there was a mutual arrangement ending amicably, and Rutherford and you and all of us shook hands, and everything went on as merry as a marriage bell; but that was subsequent; there were several meetings—I do not know the builders of the present Blackpool line—I know Chad well—I do not know that you got him to build the present line and arrange the contract.—I do not know whether the share moneys were absolutely free for the payment of the dividend; I do not know one way or the other, but I know this, that Mr. Hunter surely would have told me: he knew the ins and outs of the company far better than I did, and had there been anything of that kind he would have warned me against it and told me of it, I should think—I remember attending a meeting when the final settlement with the Blackpool Company was come to at 3i, Victoria Street—I think it was a final one—I remember it lasted about two days, or a day and a night—I think there were seven or eight solicitors present—at that final settlement cheques were given both for and against, and everything was cleared up and each one paid over, and there was a small

balance which came to us, and the thing was amicably arranged—the shareholders in the Blackpool Company did finally get their tramway, I believe; I do not know; I have never been to Blackpool since, so I cannot say very positively about it—seeing that we raised the capital to form the company, and got the tramway built, that is in my mind sufficient for our company to do, except to please the shareholders by paying a dividend—I do not know when it was completed—as a rule, tramways run for nine months to twelve before they pay dividends—if it never pays a dividend I should say we have robbed nobody if we have carried out our business in a legal and proper man from all that I know of the business it has been done properly—on the night of the dinner the company was going on most: buoyantly and prosperous—about £150,000 profit would have come to the Street Company—I think, if I remember the speech I made then, I said that I went on the Board of that Railway Company for the benefit of the Street Company; that was one of my main objects in joining Walter Webb, so as to have a control over the Walthamstow Rail
way Bill—at that time, when the dinner was on, the Street Company had every prospect of pulling off the big coup—in September, 1901, there was no reason for our wrong down the shares of the Street Company as being of small value, to my knowledge; I do not know what the financial posi
tion of the Street Company was at that moment—I knew of the railway; we had that asset—with that asset in the coffers there was no reason why we should say that we had lost the money or that the shareholders had lost the money, or that we should write down these things as money lost—I cannot express any opinion as to the value of the Street Company shares in September, 1901—the railway was certainly strong at that time—I do not remember now what was the reason of my resignation, except it was after my letter to the secretary; after that interview with Mr. Hunter we decided that we should and ought to have a meeting called; no meeting was called, and I think shortly after I sent in my resignation; I do not remember any further meetings or discussions about it—I did Not send it in because I thought something suspicious was going on with the Construction Company, but being in the position of a director, and knowing nothing about it, I thought I had better be relieved of that responsibility, whatever it amounted to, and that is why I left; I do not know if Mr. Hunter left about the same time; I think so—there was no row; there never had been any row or any reflection on the company that I know of, except that we thought we ought to have some informa
tion, being in a responsible position—I do not know if the Blackpool Company-was on at the time of the dinner—I cannot tell you where you were at that time; it is possible you were in the North of England—I do not remember that the Company involved an enormous amount of trouble, running about, and all that sort of thing—I remember what the secretary had to do, Mr. Osborne: there was a great deal to do—if we had available cash, and had seen the bankers' slips, and all that sort of thing was in my knowledge, it would seem very strange and would cause a great deal of suspicion that we should be unable to pay £2,000 or £3,000 to Hooley if we owed it—there are many syndicates, with heaps of money who are quite willing to renew on terms, as well as private people: the only thing star
ling

when speculating in these Orders would lie with the lender of the money—it Hooley was willing to renew at a fee there was nothing suspi
cious about it—the name of Lot Craven seem familiar to me, hut I never saw him I have heard of the Ito Holdsworth it Taylor and Burn & Ber
ridge were the solicitors for the Ito—I do not know that the Ito is Lot Craven and Lot Craven is the Ito in the same sense that you are the Construction and the Construction is you—what it meant to imply is, suppose, that they have raised £30,000 from Lot Craven, which is the same thing as raising £30,000 from the it Syndicate—not locked up in it, part of it free, because we had close upon £100,000, and over £100.001) coming in, which did finally come in—there is no reason why we should refuse £30,000 cash to be paid in—I may have heard of the Leeds and Wakefield Company, floated by the Ito Syndicate—I do not know it—I have heard that the Leeds and Wakefield has been established recently—I know that this very same deal ultimately led to the Leeds and Wakefield being opened a few weeks ago—I do not think I have ever come across reports of my speech in other people's hands—I do not recollect them—I never saw them in anybody else's hands but ours—none of the projects which I spoke of at the meeting could have been built-for less than £100,000, capitalized anyhow; if' none of them could be built under £300,000 or £400,000, there would be a very large profit on that—the Blackpool railway was ours, and the Leeds and Wakefield is ours—I thought there was a great deal of value in certain of the tramways that you had—I made you the proposition that if you would give me the option for a certain time of a block of these tramway shares, I thought I knew where the money Could found for them—this is a list of the Orders that I took with me to Messrs. Norton, Rose and Norton—there are more here than I had—there were about sixteen or seventeen altogether—there are twenty-seven here—it was a-list, like this that I took of our Construction Tram
ways to Messrs. Norton, Rose and Norton—I saw Mr. Turton Norton, the senior partner, and told him about the connection with you, and that I had got from you an option of these tramways, and asked him whether he could finance them, knowing he acts for big firms and for very big people in the City—he told me that he thought he could—I gave him a list, and he instructed Mr. Farish, one of his partners, to go thoroughly into the whole thing on their behalf, and Mr. Farish, I think, came down to your office once or twice aid went into these matters and made a report to Messrs. Norton, Rose and Norton—I understood everything was in perfect order, and that they were ready to carry it through, but Mr. Norton wrote to me and asked me to get the matter held over for a little, owing to the illness of his client—after waiting, I think, for a fort night, my recollection is that you would not give me any longer time and I lost the deal with Mr. Norton—that was, I should think, early in 1002—Mr. Norton took a good deal of trouble with it—I had a dozen meetings I should think—he went into it very thoroughly, and flint satis
fied me at the time that those properties were in hand, but it was a £300,000 syndicate ho was gainer to find, and you, if I remember, wanted £300,000 cash for it—they seriously entertained it and thought it was

a fair bargain; that was the basis of the arrangement—they are a very big firm, and I think they act for the Morgans as well as Sir Ernest Cassels—I had a great many meetings with Mr. Farish, and they, because we could not wait any longer, they went on with the Ito—I know I was very disappointed at the time—we went with the Ito on the Leeds and Wakefield deal.

Re-examined. Lawson gave me the option that I got for these schemes—I arranged with him as the Construction Company, and at the Con
struction Company's offices—that was his own place and the British Street Tramways—I cannot answer if it was Lawson's office, as his name is not there—it was the British Street Trains' name on the board—I did not see anybody else to get an option from but Lawson—I did not give him anything for it—no, it was a dry option—it was in writing—I con
sidered he was authorised to deal, certainly, and he satisfied Mr. Farish that he was authorised to deal—this was after I had become a director—I think Larvson signed the option—I have it put away somewhere—I know his writing—the writing on the back of this cheque looks like Fish—from October, 1901, the Construction Company would be justified if they had £100,000 to deal with, to borrow from Mr. Lot Craven £30,000 for six months—it might have a few deals on—I think any company would be justified in declaring a dividend under such circumstances—I think any company is justified in declaring a dividend out of loose cash, borrowing £30,000 with a bonus of £lo,000 for six months, with £80,000, and the dividend only coming to £6,000—I do not know anything about Lot Craven—I do not know whether they were borrowing money from him, whether I was a director or not—I was the chairman of the company, and ready, of course, to do my duty as an honourable man—I certainly did not know of the loan of £30,000—I know the handwriting of Thomas and Hunter, the directors, and of Osborne, the secretary—I see those names on me agreement dated October 1st, 1901, between the Construc
tion Company o? the one part, and Lot Craven, of Bradford, of the other part, and it says: "Memorandum of agreement made the first day of October, 1901, between the Electric Tramways Construction and Main
tenance Company, Limited (hereinafter called the contractors), of the one part, and Lot Craven, of Bradford, in the County of Yorkshire, of the other part here by it is agreed as follows: (1) The contractors hereby charge all their interest in the Orders already granted and now Her subject of application to the Light Railway Commissioners for the construction of tramways between Leeds and Wakefield and Dewsbury District to secure repayment to the said Lot Craven of the sum of £10,000 advanced by the said Lot Graven to the contractors (the receipt whereof the contractors hereby acknowledge), together with the further sum of £20,000 to be advanced as hereinafter provided. (2) The said Lot Craven will pay to the contractors the further sum of £20,000 within fourteen days from the date hereof. (3) In consideration of the said advances the contractors hereby agree that they will repay to the said Lot Craven the sum of £30,000 in cash, together with a bonus of £15,000 in castle on or before the first day of May, 1902. As further security for the said £30,000, and bonus of £15,000, the contractors will charge all

the cash subscriptions to be received by them in respect of the sale of debenture stock", ordinary and preference shares of a company to be formed for the purpose of acquiring the benefit of the said Orders, and for carrying the same into effect as a first charge for the repayment of the advances and bonus. (5) The contractors agree with the said Lot Craven that they will procure substantial underwriting for at least £100,000 of debenture stuck, ordinary and preference shares of the new company, and will also charge such underwriting with the repayment of the said advances and minus—I do not think I was present at the meeting, because I never heard of Lot, Craven—the Construction Company had agreed to defer their shares to get 5 per cent.—prospectively they were worth something—I cannot say how much—I suppose the Street Company on September 20th, when I made that speech, had a shilling—they had not-spent their money—I was not a director of it, so I cannot say—I do not know what had become of all the money that had been subscribed by the public—I know what became of the money when I was a director of the company—it had gone in the various projects; for example, the Exeter, and payment to the Construction Company and various things: expenses—there was a tidy sum left when I left the company—I said that they had a very valuable asset in the Walthamstow Railway—I valued their interest at about a half—it ought to have been £100,000 or £150,000, it it went through—I do not know that I am asked to say what I should have valued it at—on the assets not what was in the bank—the value of the shares are not represented by that—at that time there was every probability of getting the Bill—if you want to know what the betting was I should say it might have been two to one—it is hard to say what the value of the interest of the Street Company at that time was—I should think they certainly ought to have had £50,000—it is the first time that I have heard that on March 8th, 1902, the Street Company gave an option to the Construction Company to purchase the whole of their interest for ' £5,000, and only charged them fifty guineas for it—this minute says: "A. letter dated March the 18th was read, which had been received from the Electric Construction and 'Maintenance Company, Limited, asking for a three months' option to purchase this company's interest in the City and North East Suburban Electric Railway Bills at the price of £5.000, thus showing in the event of the option being exercised a profit, of 100 per cent"—that shows that they valued it at more than £10,000; it was half—"after due consideration it was resolved to Currant an option provided they agreed to pay to this Company the sum of fifty guineas for same, and the secretary was authorised to sign a letter giving the option on receipt of a letter from them agreeing to those terms"—I say that somebody not a good bargain—as a director in the Blackpool Tramway Company I drew some cheques for dividends—I signed a number—I must have been one afternoon signing dividend warrants—the line was not running then—my name was never used in connection with the company, I think to my knowledge, except at the dinner—I knew my speech was published in the "Financial News"—I did not know who made arrangements for the publication of that—it was a Press dinner—Press and engineers.

DAVID PERCY LAWRENCE . I am a clerk to James William Vickers ad
vertising agent and contractor, of 5, Nicholas Lane, Lombard Street—our firm had instructions to have a report taken of a dinner at the Hotel Cecil, on September 20th, 1901, and to cause it to be published—I think the instructions came over the 'phone—we carried. out those instructions, and sent instructions to the papers to send their reporters there—we received this cheque on account on November 25th, 1901, drawn by H.J. Lawson, payable to our firm for; £200—we had several items out against the Electric Tramways Construction Company that paid nothing-in particular—it was in respect of the dinner, and also in respect of advertising work done for the Construction Company—the figure in respect of advertising the speech at the dinner was £108 8s. 3d.

Cross-examined by Lawson. It is quite usual matter for us to report dinners and shareholders' meetings—I was given to understand the message came on the telephone—I do not know if they could tell whose voice it was—I cannot remember if the Construction Company had reports of other meetings—there is nothing unusual in it—I cannot say, but I should say there was more than £200 owing at that time besides the amount for the dinner—I am not sure.

CHARLES EDWIN FILBY . I am a journalist, of 7, Brake spears Road, St. John's, and am on the staff of the "Financial News"—under instructions I attended a dinner at the Hotel Cecil, on September 20th, 1901—I Heard a speech there made by Sir Kenneth Mackenzie—I did not take a note of the speech itself, I think it was supplied to me afterwards—I cannot remember at this time who supplied it to me—rill handed it in at the office of the "Financial News"—I produce a copy of the issue of the paper of the following Monday, September 23rd, Exhibit 125.

JAMES WATSON MILLS . I am a member of the staff of the "Financial Times," living at 13, Cheverton Road, Hornsey Lane—I attended a dinner at the Hotel Cecil on September 20th, 1901, and reported a speech then made by Sir Kenneth Mackenzie—that report appeared in the issue of the paper on the following Monday, September 23rd—I pro
duce a copy.

CHARLES WILLIAM COOP . I am a journalist on the staff of "The Statist" newspaper, and produce a copy of the issue of "The Statist" newspaper of September 28th, 1901—it contains a report of a speech delivered by Sir Kenneth Mackenzie at the Hotel Cecil, on September—20th—I received instructions with regard to that matter from Lawson—I received the first instructions from the secretary of the company, Mr. Osborne; the payment for that insertion was 20 guineas, which was arranged with Lawson; it was a five column report at four guineas a column—I produce the order under which this "was done, Exhibit 142, dated September 26th, 1901: "Dear Sirs,—Please insert full report of Sir Kenneth Mackenzie's speech at the dinner of the Electric Tramway Con
struction, etc., Company, Limited, in your next issue, to occupy columns at the rate of £1000 is per column"—it is initialled by Lawson—the first order is signed "C. Osborne"; that is one column at four guineas, and after that the order was extended to 20 guineas, and initialed by Lawson.

Cross-examined by Lawson. This was the first time I had seen you per
sonally—I do not know that it was a common practice for the "Statist" to require your initials, but I think it was so—this was a limited company, and therefore we wished to have your initial to guarantee it.
By the COURT: We were paid by me Construction Company.

ALFRED THOMAS CAMDEN PRATT . I am on the staff of the "Financier and Bullionist"—I attended a dinner at the Hotel Cecil on Septem
ber 20th, 1901, and reported the speech made by Sir Kenneth Mackenzie that appeared in the issue of our paper which I produce dated Septem
ber 23rd, 1901—I do not know personally who paid for it—it is similar to the report in the "financial News" and "financial Times"; I and the "Financial Times "reporter collaborated in the report.
By the COURT. There is nothing to show that it is an advertisement; that never is done.

JOHN FREDERICK DICKSON . I am the secretary of the Dublin Dis
tillers' Company—they have their offices at Thomas Street, Dublin—that company—was incorporated in 1889 with a capital of about £1,100,000—as regards the ordinary shares of that company they are £5 shares fully paid; no dividend has been paid on them since September 30th, 1893: the preference shares have not paid any dividend since June 30th, 1900; they paid 3 per cent, for the six months—I have got here the register of transfers of the company in November, 1900: Mrs. Hooley had as registered owner in the company 1,200 shares; on November 20th she had 1,200 ordinary shares standing to her credit; she afterwards acquired others—there were no transfers in the office in November; we did not receive a transfer until December 17th; I think that was the date; as a matter of fact, on November 24th there was a transfer for 300 shares sent from Mr. James Arnold Bradshaw, and it was received by me on the 26th—the date on the transfer was No
vember 14th—there were shares subsequently registered in her name, which brought the total up to 2,320—I have not made out what is the con
sideration in the transfers for that number: she bought them at various prices: the amount she received for them would be £1,026; she sold them at various dates; she commenced selling about October, 1900, and she cleared them off by selling to a Mr. Francis Kedfern, on March 12th 1903—I do not find that any of her shares were transferred into the name of Lawson or Ormerod: the transfer is registered with us on Decem
ber 17th from Ross and others to Mrs. Hooley, the consideration for that was £225 for 300 ordinary shares: that would be 13s. apiece—there is another, on November 20th to McCormack of Donegal; those were 50 ordinary shares for £37 10s.—there is another of the same date: Henry Richard Glynn, of Kilrush, to Mrs. Hooley, 100 shares for £75.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. Shares are often transferred without our knowing anything about it; the transfers are only lodged with us for the purpose of registration in the register, and issuing a certificate by us: again and again there are a number of transfers that take place Maintains before we got to the registration of one—sales from one to the other before somebody requires to have it registered—the registration is not a proof of what shares a person may hold or may be entitled to—

although person is only on the register for a certain number of shares there may nave been a larger number transferred to him: as an instance, in November Mrs. Hooley had only 1,200 to her credit, but as an actual fact she had 1,300—I was called at the Police Court to prove that she only appeared in the register for 1,200, whereas she purported to transfer 1,500—if it had stopped there she was purporting to transfer more than she had—my attention was called that there had been a transfer of 300 more which had not been registered in our book at the time—that once and for all disposes of the point that she had not the shares she purported to sell in November, 1900, and proves conclusively that she had those shares which she purported to sell, and that she was capable of transferring those 1,500 shares as she had purported to do; she purchased 150 shares for £155 12s. from Carson, of Dublin: he was a gentleman who apparently managed to get the best price for his shares.
Friday, December 2nd, 1904.

SIR HENRY WHITE . I am a solicitor, practising at 14, Great Marl
borough Street—I have known Hooley eight or ten years; in September, 1900, I advanced him £2,000 by way of loan—this is the cheque for 1950; I do not quite recollect how the odd £50 was made up—it is dated September 13th, 1900, pay to J.A. Bradshaw or order £1, 950, and it is endorsed by J.A. Bradshaw and paid into the National Provincial Bank of England, Limited, Piccadilly Branch; that is Mr. Ormerod's account—in September, 1901, that sum of £2,000 was still owing to me—the prospectus and the report of the speeches produced were shown to me by Hooley: I cannot say when—I was pressing him to repay the £2,000 which he owed, and he brought to my notice this Construction Company, which he thought was a very good tiling, and said if I would take 2,000, he thought he could get them for me; he then produced some plans and a list of the concessions of the company—I read in Sir Kenneth Mackenzie's speech the statements about the dividend and bonus, and the balance of £100,000 at the bank—I believed those state
ments—the first lot of shares I bought was a lot of £2,000—this is the transfer of 2,000 shares, September 24, 1901—I accepted these shares in satisfaction of the debt—this transfer dated September 11, 1901, from H.J. Lawson to Mr. Bradshaw is a transfer of all those shares identified by the same numbers—on the transfer to Bradshaw the consideration is stated to be 5s.—on my transfer the consideration is £2,000.
JAMES CUTCIXGHAM (Detective Sergeant G)—I got this letter book from Hooley's office at the Albemarle Hotel.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. I first found these books (Produced) on May 10th, 1904, when I arrested Hooley at the Albemarle Hotel, when he was carrying on his business—I seized his books—that was the first notice that was ever given to him of any prosecution as far as I know—I found copy letter books kept such as would be kept in a business, a very large number, some 20 to 30 books, ledgers, and docu
ment, a large number of original documents, and press copy letter books, with indexes—one cab was 'sufficient to take them away—I found cash books, pass books, cheque books, paid cheques, counterfoils, and agree
ments

—I think Hooley assisted us in the search and he handed me over some documents, from his private safe—he assisted in every way—is secretary helped for several hours to take these books, pack them together, and take them away—there was no attempt whatever to conceal any of them—they were taken first to New Scotland Yard—they have been there ever since, and at the Treasury—they were taken from New Scotland Yard to the Treasury—they were at New Scotland Yard some weeks—while they were there they were examined by the Treasury official,—by the police—from there they were taken to the Treasury and there examined by numbers of the officials, I believe—on May 10th. formal evidence of arrest was given—the charge was proceeded with on May 17th and various dates after—I was not always at the Police Court during the hearings before Mr. Fen wick, each being whole days devoted to this case except, the first day, when only formal evidence of the arret as taken—from July 20th there was an adjournment to September 19th, the thirteenth day, and on September '29th, the sixteenth day, of the hearing at the Police Court they were committed—this book called H 4 is the letter book from July 12th to December 5th, 1901: that is marked on it—they are all the same kind of book—there are 1,000 pages here from July 12th to December 5th.

SIR HENITY WHITE (Re-era mined.) I applied for my dividend upon the 2,000 shares and got it—this is a copy of the cheque for £226: I have seen the cheque, and I know it is correct—this is the original cheque, signed by Mr. Thomas and Mr. (Jordon Hunter, directors, and Mr. Osbornc in the secretary, and the counterfoil says: "Dividend on E.T.C. shares"—I bought a second lot of shares of this company from Hooley; I asked him if he could get me some more—this is a transfer dated November 26th 1901: Lawson to Mills 2,500 shares in consideration of £2,500—and this is a transfer dated March 17th, 1902. of 500 shares in consideration of £250 from Frank Mills to Alfred J. Paine—it includes 500 of those shares—I know nothing of them, they are not to me, and I never heard of them: I do not know why I am asked the questions—this is the transfer of December 2nd of 500 shares by Paine to me—that was part of my second purchase of the 1,000 shares from Hooley—there is another trans
fer dated December 2nd of 500 shares for £500 from H.J. Lawson to me—that was the other half of the 1.000 shares purchased from Hooley, only these transfers seem to have been signed by Mr. Thomas, a third party who is mentioned in the deed, and what his signature is there for I do not know—that was signed after: how I do not know—what I stated at the Police Court was that I was positively certain that I paid £1,000 cash for those shares, but I could not trace the actual cheques themselves—I produced two cheques of about that date, and amounting to very nearly £1.000. and I thought they must be the cheques, because I knew that I had paid cash for them—since then I have had several interviews with a gentleman from the Treasury, and have now found two other cheques—I had a private account with Messrs. Coutts, which I very rarely used; I do not think there were 20 cheques drawn in the last four or five years—I found the two cheques for £500, and both marked "For Electric Trams"—the first one is payable to C. Osborne—it passed through the London

and Provincial Bank, North Finchley—that is Obey Burton's Bank, Hooley's secretary—the second one is dated October 17th, 1901, is payable to J. Sims White, and has passed through Foster's Bank, Cambridge—I have given the Treasury all the letters I have—the meaning of my writing that I would "bring the matter before the Court "was I was very dissatisfied because I could not get my transfers registered and get a certificate—I meant to take proceedings in the Chancery Court against the transferor: that is why I asked at the end of the letter for a full description of my transferor; I have put "transferee "in the letter, but that is a mistake—my shares in the Construction Company Hooley took off my hands for the price I gave for them, because I was very dissatisfied with the Company, and I told him that I did not like the way things were being done, and that they did not seem to be doing anything, and lie said if I was dissatisfied he would take the shares from me for what I gave for them: he offered to do that himself, I never asked him to—he told me he had not got the money at the moment, but if I liked to accept a small estate in Cambridge shire which he had belonging to his wife as payment, he would take the shares as payment for it—I agreed to that—I cannot tell you the actual date of the agreement; I can give you the date of the conveyance of the estate to myself, but there was no written agreement to accept the estate; it was carried out almost immediately afterwards—the date of the conveyance is April 29th, 1903, and the probabilities are that the agreement, which was only verbal, was some time before that: I should have to investigate the title of the estate to see if Mrs. Hooley was entitled to convey it to me—that agreement was probably a month or two before the conveyance—I gave him the certifi
cates, and I signed a blank transfer—I remember Hooley producing this document to me in my office, and he asked me if I had any objection to refuse to sell my shares for six months under a certain price, and I said I had no objection at all—when I signed this document it never struck me that it was a pooling agreement at all;' I simply agreed not to sell for six months; I did not mind that; I was very busy, and I do not suppose I read it all through; it is a pooling agreement, and when I said in my letter to the Construction Company that I had no recollection of a pooling agreement, I had no recollection of this paper at all, and did not it was a pooling agreement: I see on looking at it it amounts to a pooling agreement—if I had had that in my mind I would not have put in my letter of December 26th, "your letter of the 2th inst. is the first. I have heard of any pool": all I remembered was that I had knarred not to sell for six months.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAC. When I asked Mr. Hooley if he could get me 500 more shares he said he would try—he came back some day or two afterwards, I think, and said he had got 1,000—I said I did not want 1,000: I only wanted 300, and "that I agreed to take 500 only; subsequently I said, "If you have had trouble to ret them", I will take the 1,000,"and I took the 1,000, but originally I asked for 500 only—he was not pressing or importuning me to buy shares, with regard to those last 500, certainly not—I thought Electric Tramways a very good investment—there is always more or less in

a company of that kind, in trying to get Acts of Parliament, and to carry through Provisional Orders, necessarily a certain amount of speculation in it—that is just the risk you take—it never struck me, at the moment, that what I signed was a pooling agreement—they sent me a copy of it when I wrote to the secretary, and I saw at once it was a document I had signed, and I quite admitted I had made a mistake, and that it was a pool
ing agreement—there is the word "pool "in it, I noticed that afterwards—my signature appears to lie after the signature of Mr. Paine, who signed, according to that, on October 14th—I signed on October 15th—Paine's signature was there when I signed it: it. Is above my own, and I would almost swear it was there: I have followed exactly his phrase
ology in signing it—I got 3,000 shares, for which I released a debt due mini Hooley of £2000, and I had paid £1,000 for 1,000 shares—I have no copies of the letters at-all—I did not treat it as a matter of business: it was a private matter—a general distrust of the undertaking seemed to be growing in my mind, and I told Hooley that I was dissatisfied with it—I thought the shares were not turning out as valuable as expected, and Hooley volunteered to take them back at the price given for them—he suggested it; I was complaining that I thought the thing was a failure and he said he still believed in ft, and if I was dissatisfied he would take them off my hands—it was a verbal agreement between us—I satisfied myself as to the title, and he executed the conveyance in pursuance of his word, cam-ing out the bargain in April, 1903, thirteen months before this prosecution, which was in May, 1904—I have not made any charge against Hooley in connection with the Construction Company's matters, or his sale of shares in it to me; I thought he behaved very well to me: he took them back and gave me what I gave for them—I have not sug
gested that he has defrauded me—I do not suggest it now—I am perfectly satisfied with the way in which he carried out this transaction: the estate was well worth what I gave for it: I had it valued: there was no sus
picion as to over-valuing, because it was valued for mortgage purposes—I never made any suggestion against him at all.

Cross-examined by LAWSON. I do not think I ever saw you before—I have seen A.J. Paine once or twice—I have spoken to him—I have never mentioned these shares or discussed the subject with him—I never heard Paine's name in connection with the Construction Company's shares at all—I did not know he was making £500 profit.—I did not know who my transferor was going to be—I think you may say I do not buy those shares on that circular: my recollection of that circular is that it was shown to me some time after I purchased those shares: I do not like to swear one way or the other: all I can swear is that I saw it, and it was not amongst the documents produced to me on the first occasion—only the plans and concessions were produced, but I did not see that docu
ment; when I could not say.

Re-examined. It was not upon the faith of Sir Kenneth Mackenzie's speech, or the statement in it, that I bought my first 2,000; I feel satis
fied about that—nor do I think you can say the second lot, because I cannot swear when I saw the circular—my impression is that none of my shares were bought upon the faith of the statements shown me by

Hooley, but it is impossible for me to say positively, all I know is when the matter was first mentioned to me the documents produced to me were a list of the concessions and some plans—the first certainly were not, to the best of my knowledge; the second may have been, but I do not think they were; that is all I can say; it is three years ago since I looked at that document; I cannot say when—at the Police Court my memory was not nearly so good, I should think, as it is now, because it was all sprung upon me then, and I had not looked up the documents—that was September 20th, 1904—then I swore "Mr. Hooley said that he would obtain them for me at par, and he did so; before me is the transfer for those 2,000 shares, from Mr. Bradshaw to me, it is dated Septem
ber 24th, 1901, the consideration is stated to be £2,000: it is executed by me; I cannot say whether the date had been inserted at the time I signed it; before that I had read the statements in the reprint of Sir Kenneth Mackenzie's speech, including the statement as to the dividend and bonus, and the statement that there was a balance of about £100,000 at the bank, and I believed those statements to be true and accurate—I cannot say as to whether I saw that before or after—I swore then to the best of my knowledge—I could not do more; those things were shown me at the Police Court and I was asked to read them and I did read them—when on December 20th, 1902, I wrote to the company: "How is it that a company which in 1901 paid 10 per cent, and carried forward £100,000,"and on the strength of which I pur
chased my shares, now pays nothing, and the shares are unsaleable?" I think that is a wrong expression, because I do not think I did purchase the shares on the faith of that: I may have done—I wrote "The whole matter is so unsatisfactory that I have decided to bring the whole state of the case before the Courts, as it seems to me the whole action of the company from its very commencement requires investigation."—That depended on whether I could get a satisfactory answer from the secretary—that was my impression at the time; that was my intention—I cannot say what was floating in my mind then—I am a solicitor—I was writing a solicitor's letter to the company putting forward my case—I was dissatisfied, and I simply wrote to the secretary to that effect—I have given you all the answers—I got my certificates after that, and I had great difficulty in getting those—I cannot say what the date was: that was the beginning of the trouble, and then I did not get answers to my letters—at the Police Court I considered to the best of my ability, and refreshed my memory as far as I could, and told the facts as far as I knew them—I had plenty of time—I got an intimation on June 22nd, 1904—I was not examined until September 20th—I do not remember my attention being called to the letter; it may have been—the addition to my statement I take to be the letter of the 18th, which I do not see; this may be correct for aught I know—if you show me the letter of the 15th and the enclosure I may be able to tell you that, but you put these written documents into my hands—I my have never seen it, or I may have seen it: I do not remem
ber, I do not, say I did not—I did not bring the matter before the Court—I suppose I was satisfied—I do not know why—Hooley did not take my shares off my hands as far as I recollect until the beginning of the

next year; this was in December—I was evidently satisfied somehow or another—you have tin cheque before you which drives you the date of the dividend, and you have tin-date when I purchased the other shares; I do not remember the dates—J never made a surjection that I had been defrauded. I am perfectly clear of that: I never mentioned such a thing all I said was it was at his suggestion that I bought, and that he had put me into a bad thing—that is all: I never suggested fraud of any sort, and certainly it was never any suggestion of fraud on my part that induced Hooley to buy the shares.

THOMAS ROBINSON . I am a director of the Robinson Printing Company, of 1, Lombard Court—Lawton is my brother-in-law—our company has done punting for him and for the Construction Company—Exhibit 27 was printed by our company—the order to print it would be given by the Construction Company: I cannot specify any one in person—we do not appear to have any correspondence with regard to the order; many of these instructions came through upon the telephone—I remember very well that we printed this—the order was given, not to me personally, a few days after the meeting—finding that on September 24th, 1901, we are writing sending the proof personally to Lawson does not recall who gave the order; most likely we should have instructions through the tele
phone to print a certain article which appeared in the "Financial News" of a certain date to put it into type—it is to Lawson we send it, and of Lawson we make the inquiry as to what is to go on the front page with regard to capital—after supplying a few preliminary proofs we printed a thousand copies; the first lot sent, were 250 copies, part of the thousand——there was some error in them, in consequence of which the remaining 750 copies were not delivered; as a matter of fact, they were put amongst out waste paper, 250 copies being delivered about the end of September or the beginning of October—we have our order books where the orders were entered: we have a consignment book; I have not that with me, but from that consignment-book I find that only 250 copies were sent: I cannot tell you when to a day; we made a further delivery upon October 3rd of 50 copies, and evidently it would be between September 23rd and october 3rd—we sent a proof on the 21-th—there was a further consign
ment of 22."copies sent a few days later, between the 5th and the 10th—the 50 and the 22") which were afterwards sent were a second edition, with the error in the first 250 corrected—the total delivered is 525—I held 50 shares in the Construction Company.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. Referring to the letters, it is clear I cannot, have sent any proof between September 2(th and October 3rd—(fro): "The report of the meeting of the E.T.C. Iv Co. being printed on a very hard paper, we find they are not in a fit condition for folding to-night have, however, specially prepared 50 copies, and forwarded per pas
senger train, and trust they will reach you early in the morning. We hope to be able to dispatch completion of order to reach you during Thursday or Friday."—the ink would be too wet, therefore we specially prepared 50 copies and kept the balance, which were to be dispatched during Thursday or Friday—this is on very hard paper—I do not think they were used—October 3rd was the first delivery of the new lot, the
corrected lot—I saw the old copies lying about in the company's office in London for some weeks afterwards, in Victoria Street, in a batch, as they had been delivered.

Cross-examined by Lawson. We have printed prospectuses for several large-issuing houses in London for years—when you made a public issue you ordered 200,000 or 300,000 or 400,000; sometimes after ordering, say, 50 or 100 copies, or 200 or 300 copies of a scheme all cut and dried, yon left it and would never on with it—I think you have prepared, a great many prospect uses which you have never completed—I never saw a prospectus like tin's without an application form in it, if it was a pro
spectus; we always made up an application form and sent it with the prospectus, and if it was a date there would be the date of issue at the top when the lists were opened and when the subscriptions were made, and when it would be closed, generally: not. In the proofs, in the final issue, hut always in the prospectus when it was agreed and passed by the Con
struction Company—the delivery was stopped, and all the copies that we had were destroyed—the prosecution got nothing from our office—I do not remember seeing the circulars in anyone's hands but the directors of the company and our staff—I understood the thing was discontinued when we put away the type after the final delivery of the 225 copies—when I called at the office to see you I do not think I saw you; I was shown into the secretary's room where Mr. Hunter and Mr. Thomas were; they gave me the circular back with some alterations; whether that was before we printed the final copies or before we printed the first lot, which were wrong, I cannot say—you were not consulted in my presence; I did not see you: I think you were away generally three times out of four that I called at the office—this circular has been raked up although it was destroyed years ago.

LORD JOHN REVELSTOKE . I am one of the directors of Baring Bros. Limited, merchant bankers—our company has had nothing to do with Lawson or the Construction Company with regard to the promotion of any of its schemes.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. I believe Sir Kenneth Mackenzie did come to Bishopsgate Street, but I have no recollection of what occurred; I never looked into any business which he put before me—(Read): "I believe I did have the interview with Sir Kenneth Mackenzie which he Has spoken of in his evidence here. I have read his evidence which he have here; I believe it was a substantially accurate account of the inter
view which he gave"—that brings it to my mind as far as tile Police Court concerned, and I remember or—it was about October, 1901: I will not be litter sure of the date.

Re-examined. I never looked into any such proposal—I have a very dim recollection because the interview has left no impression on my mind, in I conceive the individual who came to me went away with the impress
sion that I was even unwilling to look into the business.

RICHARD HENRY WARD . I am a physician and surgeon, practising at 46, Fetter Lane—I became a director of the Electric Tramway Trust Company, Limited—in the minutes of November 25th, 1901, I see that an agreement "November 6th was signed and executed between the Electric Tramways

Trust, Limited, and the Electric Tramways Construction and Maintenance Company, Limited: it. Is duly signed and witnessed—this agreement pur
ports to be executed by myself and Mr. Kohler, in the presence of Clement Annesley, the secretary—that is duty signature—this is a transfer by the Electric Tramway Trust. Company of 25,000 preference shares in the Con
struction Company to Lawson executed 1) me—it. Is signed by Mr. Kohler, the secretary, and myself: it is expressed to be in consideration of the sum of "s.—I was present at the meeting on June 3rd, 1902—(Further evidence, on tins point won objected to by Mr. Isaacs, and wan ruled inadmissible by the Court).

HERBERT GEORGE THOMAS . I was appointed by the directors a director of the Electric Construction Company in September, 1900; I cannot-call to mind the names of the directors at the time—I was a director two years and two months; I left in November 1902—this is my signature to this cheque to Sir Henry White as a dividend on his shares—as a director we had announced that we were in a position to pay a dividend of 12 per cent.; I cannot go any further than that—it was announced at the dinner that we were in a position to pay that: it was spoken of generally at the Board meetings—we resolved at our meetings that we were in a position to pay a dividend if necessary—I was never present at any resolution that a dividend should be declared: I was told at Bow Street that a dividend had been declared—my authority for paying £226 of the company's money on that cheque was that the recipient of it was the only man who had ever put any of his own money into the company, and he was deserving of a certain amount of interest—Mr. Paine had not put in any, that I am aware of—Sir Henry White had purchased shares for cash in the company—the company did not get it—I paid Sir Henry White money of the company because Sir Henry White was holding shares in our company, I presume—Mr. Paine held shares; is one of the syndicate that was running the company—Mr. Paine's shares were pooled, I always understood, with Lawson's, and stood with Lawson's shares—this cheque is the 8th October, 1901—I presume the best thing would be to refer to the minute book: I cannot tell you now whether there was a meeting held in that date or not—(Read from the secretary's affidavit): "No dividend or bonus was declared by the said company on the 20th September, 1901, or at any time since then"—I presume lie would not swear an affidavit to that effect unless it was true: I have even' reason to suppose that what lie swore at the time would be true—I have never seen Hooley in our office: if I have never seen him how do I know he went there: he has never been in the office to my knowledge—my name is on this transfer of 500 shares from Lawson to Sir Henry White as passing the transfer in the ordinary formal manner, I suppose a director's duties—there is another signed the same day which does not seem to have any
thing of the kind on it—I do not find any others—with a similar signature—I do not know how my name came to be there, I am sure—I received my qualification: 200 shares I think the amount was: they were handed to me by Lawson in part consideration of directors' fees and in part con
sideration of money I had invested in another company with him—in the

Construction Company I received my directors" fees in due course—I got the shares in lieu of the fees; I received the shares in part consideration—I did not get my fees as well in full—there would be a certain amount that was not paid, and it would be written off that; I presume it would go back into the company, so far as I know, in payment for the silages—it is absolutely impossible for me to remember matters of routine three or four years ago—when I left the company, on November 28th, 1902, I did not sell them—I suppose they are still standing to my name in the company's books—I have not been a director since then—I did not get any dividend on the Construction shares; they would be in the pool with the rest of the shares—the reason I did not sell them was because I did not wish to sell them—I had no thought one way or the other whether or not they had any market value at the time—I said in the Police Court, "When I left the company I did not sell them; they had no market value"—possibly they had no market, value—I am quite willing to stand by anything I have sworn—we never applied for a quotation—Lawson's position was the main and only shareholder at that, time, I believe—he would do any work, and for what he did he was in a position to demand what payment was reasonable—I should say there was no arrangement with him; he was a perfectly free agent, I should say—he would be present now and then at the board meetings—he could or could not bring a scheme to the company, just as he Irked, I always understood—the secretary and the clerks carried out the instructions by the Board—the business of the company was'the general promotion of tramway schemes, and things of that sort—Lawson would luring a scheme before the Board and would submit it, and the Board would pass it, and say what was to be done with the thing—when Lawson rough the thing to the company it would be in a cut and dried state—I looked upon him more or less as a shareholder who was following his own money, and was managing his own money—I swore in my deposi
tion, "I always looked upon him also as managing director"; that is quite correct—those were words which were, more or less, put-into my mouth at the time; they are capable of a certain amount of explanation; it is hardly fair to put it into a case of this sort, a criminal trial, that I absolutely looked upon that man as a managing director—I did leave it to Lawson to manage the affairs" of the company, in so far as his own interest was concerned, as he one man who had any hard cash involved in it—I did not say the words were sprung upon me; I adopted them, more or less; a good deal more. I should think, from my experience of it—you have "the minutes, and you know Lawson was never appointed managing director, and Lawson as not managing director—he managed his own money—when I gave the statement I explained particularly to the detectives that I was very un-certain about it, and it was promised that I should have a look through it before the depositions were taken at the Police Court, and then when the police Court proceedings were on I was cross-examined on that without having a chance of looking at it and correcting it—I told them I was uncertain about the facts I was stating there, that the matter was two wars old—I said 'I thought he was a director of the company"—I thought

so at the time, probably—as to advancing money by the company to Lawson, I cannot say anything about that now; I have no recollection of any transaction of that sort—I presume the letter of February 20th, 1900, from Lawson to "The Directors Electric Construction and Main
tenance Company Limited "was brought before me—it apparently mean hat the proposal was that fur moneys which the company advanced he was to give either cash or shares as bonus out of his profits from the pro
posed companies—he was to take the profits of the proposed companies only so far as that letter is concerned: what that letter says of course I cannot go behind—Lawson would have money as he expended it—I really do not know about any particular agreement: we had two or three dozen agreements every week—we borrowed a la rue amount of money from Mr. Lot Craven: I believe £30,000—he got 50 per cent, for the loan: I did not say 50 per cent, per annum: 50 per cent, bonus—in the letter of July 17th we agreed to 100 per cent—he would get his bonus for introducing the loan. I suppose £30,000 or 50 per cent on that, one way or the other—I presume whatever the arrangement was it was perfectly right at the time, and everything was satisfactory—I can only go so far as you have cut the facts in black and white before you—the transaction would not strike me as a director particularly—we were dealing with thousands and thousands daily—it would be a matter of ordinary routine—we night have sent Sir Henry Whites £226 in the morning, and received the loan in the afternoon you know—we were in a position to pay a dividend if we were going to ret £30,000, and pay £15,000 for having it, and make another £20,000 ourselves—paying Lawson £30,000 was nothing to us at that time with my knowledge of the Company—I am serious—we had the finest assets that any Company could have—ran you yet £30,000 on a specula
tive scheme—those assets were speculative schemes, which, if worked properly, will become worth thousands and thousands of pounds—that is the way I looked upon the thing at the time—there may be something else, you know more of them than I do—we were not payintr £45,000 for £30,000—we were paying £15,000 for £30,000 to—the £30,000 to Lawson I think was all lumped in with the various things that the Company owed Lawson—the books will show you better than I can speak from memory—I do not think that Lawson had a tithe of what the Com
pany legally owed him—there may have been also on that 1ti a com
mission, of £5,000 paid to Mr. Holdsworth, I really cannot say or there may not have been—Mr. Lot Craven was to lend £30,000 on October 1st, and it was to be repaid in seven months with £15,000—Houldsworth was to get £5,000, Lawson was to get 100 per cent, com
mission, which is £30,00 and Houldsworth was promised a further pay
ment of £10,000 as part of his commission, when payable, as and when the Company received their profits from the Wakefield, Leeds, and Dewsbury Company, does not that show the speculative nature of the loan—you are bound to pay those terms for speculations of that sort—suppose that £100 now would be worth £300 to you in a month's time, you would be willing to pay £400 for it now, if you could do a deal which you could not do without an extra £100—this was October 1st, a few days
after the speech at the dinner, at which £100,000 loose cash was talked if or cash available for dividend—even one day or half a day might make a difference in a business of that sort.
Saturday, December 3rd, 1904.

HERBERT GEORGE THOMAS (examination continued). Lawson's agreement of. I think, July 18th, was that he was to have a commission on all business he introduced to the company—100 per cent, were the original terms, I believe—on a deal of the magnitude of the Blackpool Tramway Company, £100,000. he would alter the terms, as we did eventually—on £100,000 he would have to get £100,000, according to the agreement—if Lawson brought in such a deal as would produce £10(1,000 profit lie would be en
titled to half the profit that the company made—that would be 100 per
cent—that is the best way you can work such an agreement out: it is always open to a little alteration as time goes on—the directors would de
termine the alteration, with Lawson's consent, I presume—possibly he would take the whole of the profit, I do not see why lie should not in his own company—the Construction Company was his property pure and simple, and that of the Syndicate, they were running it to
gether—there was no public money—Paine and Hooley were going to turn it into a public company—Hooley was interested with Mrs. Hooley—Lawson put the company into Hooley's hands with the eventual idea of promoting, it at such time as we did good business—the company was floated as a public company when shares were issued to the public—Lawson.
