I believe, put a large block of shares into Hooley's hands, and Paine joined Hooley with the idea that the three of us should be interested in the eventual promotion of the company as a company when it was in a fit state—the agreement of November 26th, 1000, is what I have in my mind—probably I knew all about it at the time, but it is impossible to say four years afterwards—you have the minutes, you can answer that question better than I—the £30,000 introduced applied to various schemes—I do not think the company ever got that sum for the schemes—Lawson's letter of November 15th shows that the company was in such a condition that Lawson took whatever he thought advisable—I think the books show about £20,000 advanced to Lawson at or before that time—I do not remember the deed of release, but the figures—would most certainly be put on the table at the time—the deed of release would not be signed without we knew about the terms and went into the matter—you have the minute there and it purports, I presume, to be correct—I am not saying it is not correct—the "services rendered" refer to the fact that Mr. Lawson was finding and buying Tramway Orders and things of that sort—"could always reckon that he was entitled to a fair remuneration for the work he did, independently of his engineer's fees, and his commission for introducing business on the terms of his agreement—he never pushed the point of his 100 per cent.—he dealt fairly and honestly with us—I believe there was an agreement to share the profits when the company would eventually float the Tramway Orders—I cannot say if the agree
ment was reduced to writing—we had so many agreements with one party and another, it seems unreasonable to expect me to remember it

three or four years afterwards—Lawson was the person whose resources and energy we mainly depended—lie received his remuneration or would receive it-, in die future, whether there was an agreement or not because the whole company belonged to him—if he anted, £2,000, or £3,000, or more, he would have it on account of his future dividends, and the thing worked our all right—on the other hand, if he got rid of the Provisional Orders to somebody else I do not see that it-would have an
ything to do with the company, he was not retained to work for them, and was not their servant, receiving a salary, or anything of that sort—I do not believe there was any contractual liability to supply the orders through the company—I presume he could have done what he liked with the orders provided he got them.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. The Construction Company in the way spook of as having been promoted, Hooley cannot have had anything to do with: it was to be promoted: it was a company in existence from 1SS.6; it was taken over in is Sir by Lawson under an agreement with Holroyd Smith—the first Hooley had to do with Construction shares was about October or November, 1900—Lawson, Hooley, and Paine were the only three men I knew to be interested in the balance of the Electric Construction Company's shares, 35,000—I believe I was present on November 22nd, and apparently the idea was that, after allowing for the seven signatories' shares and the 53,000 shares which had gone to Holroyd Smith that there was left a balance of 194,493, and the balance which made up the total of the 230,000 shares it was proposed to issue to Lawson for the purchase of patents, and the rights of the Motor Wheel—it was brought before the company, and approved, that Lawson was to get the right to deal with the 194,1-93 shares—at that time the Street Company's shares were about to be issued—that company, it was always understood, should be a great success—if so. It would mean the acquisition of a con
siderable profit to the Construction Company—I saw Hooley for the first time to my knowledge at Bow Street Police Court in these proceedings—I do not know that he was concerned in the management of the affairs of the Construction Company—I heard that suggestion made to me at Scot
land Yard—I was asked whether I knew, or had seen Hooley, or whether lie had anything to do with the business, so I replied, "No," and that only on one occasion when Hooley and Lawson were going somewhere together Hooley called at the office for him—Hooley had nothing to do with the Street-Company—I know nothing about the Trust, Company—the loan from Mrs. Hooley of £3,000 to the Construction Company was the most reasonable loan that we obtained during the course of our business—a bonus was to be paid in the £2,000 preference shares of the Blackpool South—there was nothing in a loan of £'5,000 at 3 per cent., nor in agree
ing to give for the use of that money £2.000 in shares out of the shares which the Construction Company was going to get as its profit for carry
ing out the Blackpool South—I saw nothing reprehensible or objectionable in that transaction—that bonus of £2.100 is the £'2,000 of Blackpool 5 1/2. per cent, preference, and the £100 given for accepting the post-dated cheques for £2,000 and the interest £38). 9s. 9d., the cash paid was £2,138 leaving a balance of £3,000. which represented the liability to Mrs. Hooley

as evidenced by the post dated cheques of October 16th and Novem
ber 16th—the £250, I presume, was Mr. Oliver's bonus—the company did not pay cash when it could pay in shares—according to the balance sheet produced the tens of Cardinal Kebob, Oliver, and Mrs. Hooley were very dues—I presume they were about the best terms obtainable—the Founders' Syndicate borrowed £5,000, the bonus payable in shares and cash, and the promotion of the Blackpool was £10,000—Mrs. Hooley was lending upon substantially the same terms on which everybody else outside and unconnected with the Construction Company was lending money to that company.

Cross-examined by Lawson. The promotion of this Construction Com
pany was abandoned—it has never been carried out to this date—the knowledge that the directors obtained from you was very useful to the business that was being discussed daily—several of the directors fre
quently met at the office to discuss the business of the Company—I was on an average with the Company at their offices three times a week, and matters were often discussed with the secretary, Mr. Osborne, who was a very able man, and I always endeavoured to do as much as I thought right in the interests of the company—my father's business was in the boot trade: I managed it for him, and I also had some interest in a Trac
tion business—I have met a good many kinds of directors in the course of my business, and I should think that I knew as much about my business as they did theirs—Mr. Paine's shares were not bought, because he never paid for them, and I had not anticipated that he would ever pay a farthing for his shares—as far as I know he was friendly with everybody—I had hoped all along that the Company would get hold of something very good to float, and I always thought that was the Company's intention—in 1901 and after the dinner in 1902 the Company fell into your hands, and therefore became a private company absolutely—there were a dozen shareholders, but, as far as I know, not one of them paid a single sovereign in the Company—I remember a minute somewhere about October 8th, 1901, at a meeting at which I was present, when it was resolved "That 1.450 ordinary shares of £1 each, numbered 55,508 to 59,957, be and they are hereby allotted to Mr. H. J. Lawson, for which he has paid the Com
pany the sum of £4,450"—I should think that a vote given by you would result in whichever way you wished it to—I understood Paine was interested in the future flotation of the Company—he came to tin? office several times to see how things were going on, thinking he was going to make a lot of money like the rest of us, who I think will do so even yet—I think I first knew Paine about the end of December, 1900—the general idea I thought then was that we were going to float the Com
pany as a public Company, and it was common talk in the office that Hooley had floated other companies very successfully in which you had an interest—as far as I knew, you had never asked anything unreasonable or exorbitant in connection with the Company—we always thought that it paid the Company when we lent you any sum like £3,000, for when at the end of 1960 you first took up the Company, to the best of my belief it never had a shilling piece, but to-day it has several large schemes-and projects which have cost the Company over £20,000 in out of pockets,

and when I resigned in October or November, 1902, the assets were in a very rosy state—I should think roughly the greater amount the company advanced you was £5,000, but I do nor remember signing any cheque for that amount—I believe the work you did in connection with the Blackpool company involved a considerable amount of cash, and to my knowledge you had to £m about, and meet several shareholders to make. deals with them for cash, and that would amount in tens of thousands—I should think if the Wakefield, Nottingham, or the Blackburn project were going to be done properly, they would amount to over £5,000—as to the law expenses if has been publicly stated by Sir Douglas Fox in the House of Looks that £20,000 was a considerable sum for the costs of a great railway bill—the Leeds and Wakefield, to the best of my belief, has been a very satisfactory business to the Company—Lot Craven first of all, I believe, nor security for his £30,000 by taking over the Leeds and Wakefield Order—you introduced 30,000 sovereigns into the Com
pany—if Lot Craven's deal ends in his ettinir £10,000 cash and shares in the Leeds and Wakefield Tramway the Company would make £20,000 profit, out of which we should have to pay Houldsworth his commission, and the Company could still afford to Pay you whatever the directors thought was a fair and reasonable sum—that was an excellent deal of the Company I think, and I would do it every day if I could—I should not have remained a director for two wars if my opinion had been that the Company was a sham—I see no fraud anywhere—out of the 60,000 shares issued, 55,000 were in Holroyd Smith's agreement—4,450 you paid cash for and the qualifications would make 7.0 more—practi
cally the lot belonged to you, because there was some agreement as to Holroyd Smith's shares—I believe that 15,000 out of the 55,000 shares Were in the name of Holroyd Smith—afterwards you were them up—Smith's option was never acted on, and I believe practically the whole of the shares belonged to you, and you had a perfect right to control the Company, I thought, and think so now—you were working very hard to get subscriptions for the Leeds and Wakefield Order, to get it taken up—each preference share is a £1,000 share—I believe it is perfectly legal to have a "One Man Company"—if I wanted to register a "Thomas Limited "1 should try to do it in the cheapest possible way as you did—in the case of Eye r. Solomon, the man had his wife and daughter for directors, and vet the House of Lords supported it—I know as a director that a profit was made in the Leeds and Wakefield to the Com
pany between the purchase price and what Lot Craven eventually settled for—we should not have taken the Order unless we got a profit on it—I believe you are still interested—I attended scores of the City and North East Suburban Railway meetings which went though the east of London to Walthamstow. Bethnal Green. Hackney Downs, and many other stations—I thought it was likely to be one of the finest railway schemes that was ever thought of in connection with London, it would have taken the poor people out of these crowded neighborhoods into the country, and landed thorn near me—probably it would have taken them into cheap dwellings where they would have to pay less rent, and the Company would probably have made a very lame profit £300,000 or in per cent, on

the undertaking—I heard that Morgans agreed to finance it, or back it to the extent of £2,000,000—a success of that magnitude would justify everything you have done the last two or three years—I am not ashamed of anything we, as directors, have done—I only regret Paine's allegations is to the price of his shares—Paine brought or threatened an action against the Street Company—writs were served—I expect he had a cheque or something to settle it—he put articles in newspapers, and issued letters in every shareholder asking 2s. a share—in one or two papers I think I saw somethinglof it—I think he got about £937 to leave us alone, or 7s. Gd. each for 2,500 shares we had given him—on the pooling agree
ment lie signed for.",000 shares, 3,000 of which he had exchanged with Hooley for something else, as we know from his letter, and his transfer, which was of no consideration—somebody interfered with Holroyd Smith, an a created an unpleasantness between him and the Company—he had £200 in cash and 3,000 shares to settle it—this £200 cheque to A.J. Paine has your signature and Paine's endorsement—as a director of Com
panies I know that hundreds of dividends are paid between annual mee
tings on the estimate of directors only, and the shareholders read of it for the first time in their morning papers—the balance sheet is made on the directors' ideas of things—the Articles of Association gave us power to do every thing that we used to do—we could pay 12 per cent. Or any
thing we liked, and were in a position to pay—the balance sheet was pre
pared some time after the dinner. I think—we felt we could afford £6,000 in dividend—I heard the speech at the dinner—you had other work—Paine was invited—I have not heard of any person who has written to the office and complained of Sir Kenneth's statements—I saw—the "' proof "not the "manuscript "before the bulk of the circulars were printed—Hunter and myself revised it—Hunter was one of the committee—the circular was practically the same as a grocer's handbills, I had no idea it was going to be used for asking people to subscribe for debentures or shares—this is correct: "It was printed with the sole object of being put before the local authorities or engineers, who did not know what we were doing, or had been doing"—that circular shows that Mr. Ward, of Ward, Bowie and Company, was present at the meeting—the idea put in it was not a bogus one—in it the debentures appear as at the nominal value of £250,000—circulars were sent as a matter of courtesy to sub
scribers to correct their speeches—when we were not in a position to pay the dividend, and there was probable litigation the documents were locked "p—six out of a dozen shareholders were present at the meeting—I never knew Henry Times to attend a meeting after that date, his resignation appears in the minute dated September 8th.1399—Hunter was then a director, and Rawlings was a director of the Blackpool—I believe we had some shares in this Company—Mr. Edge was a shareholder—Chad well was our engineer, but not a genuine shareholder, as he never paid any money for the shares, you bought them for £400—everything that-you have done for the Company has proved advantageous to it. I know of nothing that he did to involve the Company in a big loss—the Company tad nothing, "in a way, at the start—I know nothing of the work they are doing now—I recognise the Blackburn. Whalley, and Burnley, as being

one of the old contracts about the time I left the Company—I never went down to any meetings of the Light Railway Commissioners, Lytham I recognise those schemes as being those they had in the Office at the time I was there, they have cost us tens of thousands of pounds—Tramway Orders, and Railway Bills are always a great speculation—I should not think, we would take up another under £200,000—the Orders costing £5,000 or £10,000 would show a large profit to the Construction Company—we worked upon the same measure at Blackpool.

Re-examined. Lawson had got all the shares mentioned in the pool by transfers of shares—probably they are still on the register, except Chad
well's—I do not know what became of Sir Henry White's shares—Colonel Harris swore at the Police Court that he had paid for his shares—pro
bably he was the only one who paid direct to the Company for the shares—they were transferred back to Lawson—I have heard him say that they were Osborn's and Lawson's—I do not know what Lawson gave for them—Harris said that he had inquired as to what had become of his shares, but could get no information—there is a letter to Lawson of October 16th, H—Colonel Harris says, according to the papers, that he gave a transfer for his shares—I cannot remember what the secretary said about Colonel Harris writing about his shares—I should not think that the secretary would give a shareholder inspection without the consent of the Board—after Osborn left Lawson he went as a secretary to some business in the Strand—it is about four months now since I have seen him—I believe Colonel Harris signed a transfer—he might sign in two different names—I do not understand the transfer book, it being accountants' work who looks after these tailings—the circular of the dinner was printed by the Robinson Printing Company, and in it were mentioned the debentures.

WILLIAM WATSON RUTHERFORD . I am Watson Rutherford. & Co., solicitors, Liverpool—I first met Lawson in the spring of 1901—he was introduced to me as a gentleman who was purchasing shares from shareholders in—the Blackpool (St. Ann's and Lytham) Tramways Com
pany—I had no knowledge whatever of the Electric Traction and Main
tenance Company—he informed me that he had purchased or agreed to purchase a considerable number of shares in the Blackpool (St. Ann's and Lytham) Tramways Company, Limited, and had acquired a controlling in toast in liar Company, that there was a scheme to convert if into elec
tric traction, and that an Act of Parliament had been obtained for the purpose—at that time this particular tramway was being run with gas engine tramcars—he said he was forming a new company, or had formed a new company for the purpose of acquiring the whole of the shares and other interest of the old company, and to canny the scheme out—the Blackpool Electric Tramways (South) was the name of this new Company—I negotiated with a view to finding capital for the Company, and it was then that I became aware of the agreement between it and the Construc
tion Company of June 26th.1001—I knew the name, but I did not know any details about the Construction Company—that agreement recites an agreement of March 10th, by which the Construction Company had acquired the right to purchase majority of the shares of the Blackpool (St. Ann's and Lytham) Company, and it also recites that the Construction

Company propose to pay oil "the debentures of the old Company, and dis
charge its liabilities—by this agreement the Blackpool (South)"agreed to issue to the Construction Company £150,000 debenture stock, £100,000 per cent, preference shares, and £150,000 ordinary shares, fully paid, except as to £50,000 of the shares, and in consideration of this issue the Construction Company undertook to complete the purchase of the shares and debentures of the old Company, paying of! their liabilities and to convert the line into electric traction, equip it with electric cars, and give it £0,000 working capital—the proceeds of the issue of the £150,000 de
benture stock were to be placed without deduction to a separate banking account in the names of trustees—the exact, words are set out in the fifth paragraph of the agreement—there was to be a certificate given subject to a decision of the engineer as to the sum required—there was a trust deed of July 11th, 1901—I procured three guarantors for the £150,000—0:1 August 1st we completed our guarantee by putting in applications for the exact balance of the money then subscribed, making up the £150,000—the money was eventually all paid, and we performed our contract absolutely—I remember meeting Lawson with Mr. Kitchin on August 3rd—we paid our money in and made up our guarantee to the £150,000, and we asked Lawson for the remuneration which under the contract we were to get, and he said he was not in a position to pay it—I had given notice to the bank not to part with any of these subscription moneys either for the debentures or the shares without consulting us, and on that very Saturday morning I received a letter from the bank in London to the effect that Lawson's solicitor had been to see them and that they were unable to act upon the stop order which we had given him—I. com
plained to Lawson about this, and he said that his company were entitled to draw out the money if they wished—I do not think that Lawson ever claimed in any way to touch the debenture stock money, but this was the share money—as a matter of fact, both the debentures and the share money were payable, under the contracts which you have, to the Electric Tramways Construction and Maintenance Company, Limited, and it was their duty afterwards to transfer the debenture stock money to the credit of the trustees, and this part I was afraid they would not carry out—the matter was settled by an agreement dated August 9th, 1901, between the Construction Company and the guarantors—all the difficulties and errors with regard to the banking account were after considerable discussion and difficulty settled and the arrangement was incorporated in the deed which was duly executed—there was a meeting held on August 30th, of the ilirectors of the Blackpool (South), at which I was present, and Lawson was also there at 34, Victoria Street, Westminster—at that meeting the statement made as to the number of shares sold to the public under the prospectus was that it was between 95,000 and 100,000—these shares were payable by instalments, so much on application, so much on deposit, and mi much on certain dates—the date was about half-way, so that sub
stantially there would be roughly about £50,000—eventually we obtained from Lawson and his company £22,500, being part of the £30,000 which we ought to have had, and "through this they were entitled, on paying over those moneys, to withdraw cash towards their own expenses of the promo
tion

and so on, in the proportion of two against three, which would be about i'17.(100—they stated that their total promotion expenses were £20,000 and that they had £30,000 to pay to the guarantors in connec
tion with the whole issue to cover all the expenses, and it was considered that anything drawn out should us in proportions of 30 to—0—I do not know how much the Construction Company had drawn out by Septem
ber 20th—they had idiot purchased all the shares and debentures of the old Company—they had purchased a considerable number of shares in the old Company, but they had not purchased them all, and they had not discharged the liabilities of the old Company, or provided the £5,000 working capital, or the cars—the tramway was constructed, and it has been runnier since about Aultim.1!)()."!-no dividends have been paid to any shareholders as yet.

Cross-examined by MR. ISAACS. had nothing whatever to do with Hooley all through my connection with Lawson and the Construction Com
pany—we thought when our Hun took this matter up.
