sideration of the sum of five shillings, paid by James Arnold Bradshaw, of 4, York Buildings, Sweeting Street, Liverpool (hereinafter called the said transferee), do Hereby bargain, sell, assign, and transfer to the said transferee 2,000 shares, numbers 4."J,0Ol to 47,000, in the undertaking called the Electric Tramways Construction and Maintenance Company, Limited, to hold unto the said transferee, his executors, administrators, and assigns, subject to the several conditions on which I held the same immediately before the execution hereof; and I the said transferee, do hereby agree to accept and take the sudd shares, subject to the condition aforesaid. As witness our hands and seals, this eleventh day of September, in the year of our Lord, one thousand nine hundred and one.—Signed, sealed and delivered by the above named. H.J. Lawson. In the presence of Charles Osborn, 40, Holborn Viaduct, E.C., secretary Signed, sealed and delivered by tlie above named James A. Bradshaw. In ihe presence of Albert J. Fox, Liverpool, broker."

HENRY HAVELOCK JACKSON . I am in the Patent Oflice as second division clerk, under the Comptroller—I have made a search in the Patent Office as to certain patents of Mr. Holroyd Smith—I produce the registers showing the agreement of February 14th, 1899, on the file of the Construction Company by which Holroyd Smith purported to assijm certain patents—there are ten of those patents which I have identified by their numbers, and their years, which have all expired—there is one in 1902 and the rest but one in 1!'():' and one in March, 1901—I have not any in 1901—5848, year 1900. date of expiry March 29th. 1904—I have also searched the file with reference to certain patents granted to Ludwig Kpstein for improve
ment in electro propulsion of vehicles and vessels—Patent No. 15,564 of 1895 is still in force—the current year's fee was paid Xovember 21st, 1904—there was a penalty due at that time for not having paid it before of £5—that was also paid—Patent No. 5258 of 1897 became void "a February 25th, 1904. for non payment of fees—there is also a patent relating to improvements in motor cycles to H.J. Lawson, 21686 of 1898—I do not find any 21686 of 106—the former became void on October 14th, 1902, by non payment of renewal fee—that is one of those included in that release of Jnnuarv 28th, 1903—there is another of 2841 of 1899
which is also in the deed—that became void on February 8th, 1904, by nun payment of the fees—the next in the deed is 7002 of 1900—there was a three months' fine of £5 paid on that.

Cross-examined by Lawson. It is common to take out fresh patents and supersede them by improvements—my answers about Holroyd Smith do not include every patent taken out by Holroyd Smith; they only include certain numbers which I have on a sheet—they do not refer to French patents.
By the COURT. I did not look to see whether there were subsequent patents to the last taken out by Holroyd Smith.

FRANK FROEST (Further cross-examined by MR. ISAACS.) When I went to he Albemarle Hotel and saw Hooley he made no difficulty at all—I told him it would be necessary to search his office, which had been moved from Walsingham House to the Albemarle Hotel—he said: "Very well, here are the keys of my private safe"and handed the keys to me—he said his secertary, Mr. Campbell, would give me the keys of the other safe; and he gave me every assistance—I was present at the Police Court when Mr. Avory was cross-examining Mr. Paine with reference to some conversations with Mr. Holroyd Smith, but I cannot give any details—Mr. Holroyd Smith was present during a number of days—he had been subpœnaed by the Treasury and a statement had been taken by the Treasury from him.
———BURCH (Detect hr Sergeant Sew Scotland Yard)—I arrested Lawson on May 10th last.

Cross-examined by Lawson. I told you you would be charged on a warrant with conspiring with Hooley to cheat and defraud A.,1. Paine of various sums of money You said, 'I have never had a shilling of Mr. Paine's money in my life, and Mr. Paine knows it"—between 30 and 40 statements have been taken of different people not 50 or 60—I cannot say positively—we have not called them all—they have been submitted to the Treasury and they have dealt with them as they thought fit—while the case has been on, people have called at Scotland Yard to lodge complaints against you and the company—I cannot tell you the names now; I could get them out for you—there have been none who have lost money in the Construction Company.
JAMES SHORROCKS (Re-examined by Lawson). The total credits from the commencement of the account up to September 24th, 1901, comes to £176,891 6s. 2d.

p.hi: submitted that there was no case to go to the Jury against Hooley, as there was no evidence of a conspiracy between Hooley and Lawson to defraud the shareholders in the Construction Company; that there was no evidence that Hooley had aided and abetted Lawson as manager of the Construction Company to make false statements, for it could not be supposed that Lawson was manager de jure or even manager facto, and that all the witnesses directly connected with the Company had declared that Hooley had had nothing to do with its affairs. Lawson also submitted that there was no case to go to the Jury against himself, there being no evidence of his having conspired with Hooley to defraud Mr. Paine.

counts must go to the Jury, and the others should be allowed to remain for—the present. That if the other counts were struck out the facts involved in them would still be open to be dealt with under the conspiracy counts.

div1.p:
Hooley, in his defence on oath, said that he knew nothing of the Construction Company except what Laivson told him; thai he only told Paine what Lawson told him about, the Company and nothing else: that he told Paine nothing which he himself did not then believe to be true; that he had never conspired u'ith Lawson to defraud Paine or the shareholders in the Construction Company; thai he had never represented to Paine thai the Company had earned sufficient cash to pay a divi
dend of 16s. on each share within a few days; thai the contract between Lawson and himself of November 26th was bona fide; that he had never represented to Paine that Lawson had possession of 245,000 shares in the Company, or that that number had been issued at that date; or thai the Dublin Distillers shares were worth £5 each, and were readily saleable at that price; and that he believed the printed documents which Paine saw were all true.

CHARLES CHADWELL . I am an Associate of the Institute of Civil Engineers—I have had a long experience fn the work of construction (if tramways and light laihvays and the preparation of Parliamentary Papers—I have carried out electric tramways for the Dover, Southend, Devonport and Plymouth Corporations and others—I was retained by the Construction Company in connection with the Blackpool Tramways—upon the instructions of the Company I prepared plans and specifications and took out all the different quantities for the electrification of the Blackpool tramways—I know that for many months you were engaged in buying up the old Tramway Company and visiting the different shareholders, of which I was one—I do uot think I was present at any of the Board meetings—Mr. Xevins based his estimate upon the estimates and quantities and books of dimensions and weights and costs—I have the quantities and specifications here which I prepared—there are two specifi
cations; one is for a permanent way and the other for electrification—I have no knowledge of the plant that Mr. Xevins sent to Blackpool—I only know that he told me he was sending some plant down—I never saw any estimate of his or any contract by him to put plant and material there—I believe he drew up a contract and settled it with the Construction Com
pany—I saw (he contract—Mr. Xeviris signed a duplicate of this (Produced) which was the basis of the whole estimate—Mr. Nevins's tract was not carried out, because he died—I constructed the Blackpool Electric Tramways—I have acted as engineer for the Construction Com
pany in many matters—I daresay I have received from the Company or from you many thousands of pounds—I was appointed after having pre
pared the specification and quantities—Xevins tendered upon it; then he died and I was approached by the Construction Company to undertake the contract.—I did the work on practically the same terms as Nevin's contract—F, commenced the work of construction about December, 1903—I believe the delav between Xevin's death and mv commencing the work

was owing to certain disputes going on between Mr. Rutherford and the Cunipanv—I believe Rutherford wanted to get the business into his own hands and the Company wanted to keep it and carry the work on for themselves—if the Construction Company had carried out their contracts 1 think the Company would have been a great success—it was part of their original intention to carry the tramway from Lytham to Preston—they applied for that extension at two separate Sessions—I acted as engineer for the Parliamentary work for the Construction Company—I believe it was also part of the Company's original scheme to obtain run
ning powers all over the Corporation tramways of Blackpool; as a matter of fact the Blackpool South are applying now to the Corporation, for such powers—I believe they have a Bulodged in Parliament to attain that object—the Lytham and Preston line was tlirown out owing to the opposi
tion of the Lancashire and Yorkshire, and London and North-Western Railway Companies—I do not know what was in the minds of the Con
struction Company but having been beaten twice it is obvious they would want to get their money back—you gave evidence before the Light Rail way Commissioners in Preston Town Hall—I remember you putting in the pass book—I do not know about producing the money for carrying out the work—at the first application the London and North-Western Hailway raised a questi'on as to the financial position of the promoters-to carry out the scheme, and it was tlirown out owing to the fact that the London and North-Western Railway said that there had been so much money paid for raising the debentures that they did not think it was fair that the promotion should go on; with the result that the scheme was thrown out on the question of finance—at the next application the Com
pany were satisfied that the finance was all right—the obviously. proper. course then was for us to immediately apply to Parliament—that is the usual course of tramway work—if we lose it before the Light Railway Commissioners we go to Parliament—of course this was rather an excep
tional case—the Lytham and Preston line was a competing line with the joint lines of the London and North-Western Railway and—the Lancashire and orkshire—so by your being weak in tlie finance on the first occasion it gave the Commissioners a right to objecting to the line because there is a clause in the Act which prevents the Light Railway Commissioners granting a line where there is the slightest element of competition—that can be got over by applying to Parliament—the second application was in November, 1902—there was a hearing at Preston last June but by different promoters—it was Preston to Blackburn and Preston to Lytham—there "were two applications—I acted as engineer to both—'the question was that the money was not put up locally—there was sufficient money found, but it was given in evidence that you had-some connection with it—as a matter of fact you had not—for that it was tlirown out—if the original intentions had been carried out in the prospectus I think the Construction Company would have had a grand scheme in the Black-pool Company, and I think the Blackpool Company would have been la veiy great success—I think the Blackpool Company will be a success if they £it the running powers over tlie town of Blackpool—I take. It that the'Construction Company found all the money required to enter into a

contract to construct the line, which would have been completed had not Mr. Nevins died and these disputes arisen—judging from the evidence you gave to the Light Railway Connnissioners I think the Construction Company was in a position to cany out these contracts—I took over the contracts at practically the same price as Mr. Nevins, which was £70,000 in cash and £30,000 in shares—I took these over owing to pressure by Mr. Rutherford of Liverpool, who came to me and asked whether I would take tin's contract—he had had twelve or eighteen months' dispute with Liwson and he had been nominated Lord Mayor of Liverpool and he dare not take this contract unless these disputes were settled—when I took the contract from him he said: "There is so much cash and so many shares and if it does not see you through I will sec you through."—I take it the Construction Company was in a position to earn out its contract with my assistance—I would have taken the job from the Company pro
vided they had made the same arrangement as Mr. Rutherford and carried it out—Mr. Rutherford called on me about the beginning of September, 1902—he asked me if I would take the contract over—I have taken it over and have carried it out and the line is loaded and running now—I have been retained by the Construction Company on a number of other tramway works besides Blackpool including Exeter—I did the sur
veying there and at Accrington and Burnley—I should say that £20,000 would be well within the mark for the probable cost to you or the Con
struction Company of all that work, the promoting expenses and the Parliamentary payments—I know that the Construction Company had on hand a large number of such projects—it is obvious witli the liabilities ard resposibilities that they take that there should be a large margin of profit upon the outlay to the promoters and it is common knowledge in general that large profits are made on such undertakings—the risk taken is very great—it depends upon who the promoters are and how the case is worked up whether the applications go through: but even with the best promoters and the best Parliamentary agents only a percentage go through—it is difficult to get people to put their money up—I do not know of my own knowledge that if people put up £1,000 they expect to et £2,000 back for it in the event of success—the Construction Com
pany is at present engaged upon a large tramway undertaking in the North of England—if they get their proposed extensions it will involve a capital of something considerably over a million of money—it would take years of hard work for you at each Session to get a little bit more and a little bit more of the extensions—the undertaking will give the Construc
tion Company a very large profit if properly handled—it is entirely a speculation.

Cross-examined. I never constructed or promoted anything for the Construction Company—I was retained by the Company—I am not a promoter—I know nothing about the capital of the Construction Company—a good deal of the success of these great undertakings would depend on honest finance and on the company that undertook them having proper capital with which to carry them out—I should not expect a reasonable return if in cany ing them out at every step they had to borrow money at 100 per cent.—T know nothing about the management of the Construction
Company—I was simply retained as an ordinary professional man—I knew nothing about the directors or of Lawson's arangemcnt with the Company.

Re-examined It is unusual for a professional man when he receives a retainer to know anything of the financial stability of the company—I was retained and was always paid my professional fees—I do not say that there no no profits in building a tramway when 100 per cent is being paid for the expense of putting up the Bill—I was asked whether if the Company was honestly and properly worked it would pay and if they paid 100 per come for borrowing money it would pay—that is quite a different question to the ordinary carrying out of a contract—if a company borrowed £2,000 or £10,000. at 100 per cent, it would not make much difference, but if it borrowed £200,000 or £300,000 it would make all the difference.

THOMAS GREKSHILL . I am from Messrs. Sims and Synies, solicitors—I have had large experience in registering companies and syndicates for iliirty years—I cannot say for certain how many companies or syndicates I have registered: about 1,000 or perhaps more—I am a Borough alderman—I came to know you through doing some work among the working men in Hampstead; I should think about eighteen mouths or two years—this (Produced) is a copy of the assignment of the Epstein patents to you—it is an attested copy and I have examined it with the original—it is assigned on July 13th, 1900—the original patentee is dead and this ia by his executrix and it purports to assign the two patents—the consideration is the transfer to her of 3,000 fully paid up shares of £1 each in the British Motor Company, Limited—I cannot say whether there was any cash, but it does not purport to have been passed for any cash—in July or August this year there was an offer made for what is known, as the Blackburn Order of £6,000 less £1,000 commission and afterwards of £10,000 and then of £6,000 and then of £10,000 again, but the company would not take it or you would not—they are bond fide orders—I made inquiries from the client.

By the COURT. There are some companies formed to take over at once a manufacturing business or otherwise whereby they come immediately into possession of property—at other times it is simply a company formed with merely paper concessions.

By Lawson. The usual course when speaking about tramways is to have some men who put themselves together, speculators, with, the object of getting an order; thy find money—sometimes they do it privately, sometimes through the medium of a syndicate registered under the Companies Act—the usual course of business is not to have a large company either for construction or for working—I do not know why or that there is any principle in it except that it is the usual course, and is more expedient than anything else, but the syndicate would have a certain amount of capital, and that capital would be subscribed by generally a limited number of persons paying a certain amount of money each into it, and they would promote the Bills by their nominees—usually the object of the company would be to promote the Bill and everything that is incident to it, and that would be done by the syndicate—the funds of the

syndicate or company would be used lor that purpose—there are many small syndicates with about £30,000 capital—I had nothing to do with the Nottingham and Derby—the usual course is if you have a concession in West Africa to employ first of all by means of a syndicate an en
gineer, or someone who would go and prospect the country, or prospect what
ever there was, and you would get the report back, and if you found there was a lot of copper you would form a Copper Company, and the syndi
cate, which would be called the parent syndicate, would get the advan
tage of the profit made in selling the copper part of it; another company might be for coal, and they would sell that again and make a profit out of the coal deal—if it is a £30,000 syndicate the man might bring it to my office and we find people to put up £5,000 or £10,000 to begin with; there is nothing remarkable in that—it is remarkable, but it is the usual thing to give people £2,000 who had put up £1,000—I have known them to have a great deal more and a great deal less; it depends on the circumstances; a concession or a promotion of a Bill are both speculations—I have never put my money on it yet—I do not think I should if I was offered 3 to 1—so far as the finance is concerned, very often it is immaterial who the directors are, but if you aregoing to put forward the company that is promoting the Bill; when I was on the Council we used to scrupulously look into who the parties were, and their funds, and everything connected with them; bat if you are speaking of finance, if the money is found, it does not matter twopence who the promoters are unless you are going to use the company for the purpose of promoting the Bill, and then it is quite a different affair.

Cross-examined. "When £2,000 is given for £1,000 it is generally tried to be got back, but not always successfully—if the Bill is a success it comes generally out of the public in the end—if it is not a success, as it very often is not, it comes out of the pockets of the promoters—assuming the thing goes through and is eventually floated to the public, the 2 to 1 is put in for the public to pay up—it is like talking about working classes and the increment of the land; it all comes from the increment of the land as all this comes from the public—the public are getting to know something about the 2 to 1 now—of course, an honest company would put their contract out and say "Here is the deal; if you like to come into it, well and good"—if we are drawing a contract we insist upon telling everything from the very start—that used not to be so—this offer which I spoke about was only put before Lawson that I am aware of; it arose since this prosecution commenced—they thought the prosscution would enable them to get it a good deal cheaper—the offer was not a very handsome one—they would not accept it—I think Lawson was "they"—I think the promotion of the Bill cost £10,000—I advised Lawson and his company under circumstances of this kind to get the £6,000, and I thought Mr. Paine might have got part of it—there was no 2 to 1 in it—I think I can honestly say the Construction Company is in a position to consider some things—I think they have got the necessary number of directors—I think by the articles they continue till another

board is appointed—if, according to the last return, there are-only, two directors, they have not got a quorum—I think a quorum in companies might act for the purpose of appointing others—Lawson was like: the man in the "Mikado,"he was the chancellor and everything rolled into one, and when you went to Larson you went to the company—I had no Construction shares.

By the COURT. In every project where you are finding money by speculation of this kind, whether a Bill or a Light Railway is promoted, you give 2 to 1 the person who finds the money, and it is quite a common practice to also give something to the person who introduces that percon—it varies, sometimes it is 5 per cent., sometimes 10 percent.—I have even known them to give more than that—I have, even known them to give 3 to 1, and also something else—it depends on the nature of it—if it is a wild-goose scheme you might have to pay very dearly. but if it is a probable and reasonable scheme, or what I might call a first-rate scheme, then you would have to pay 2 to 1,-unless you had some gentlemen who are promoting workmen's dwellings, where the real object is not money, but assisting a certain class, then probably you would not—if you take it among general speculators you have to give 2 for 1 for each pound that is put up either for registration or for' pro
moting a Bill or for anything else.

HARRY HEWITT GRIFFIN I am one of the oldest of the veterans in cycles and motors that took actual part in the establishment of the in
dustry in England—this (Produced) is a photograph of the motor wheel known in the trade as the motor wheel patent—it is about to be intro
duced—I have seen the machine—I have a very high opinion indeed as to the possibilities of this invention—it is a missing link that has been wanted to bring it in with-other vehicles—it can be used in connection with existing vehicles—at present the motor car requires to be separate, but with this it can be added to an existing vehicle, and it will become the universal motor, and it will cause great iraprovemments in the motor car—it is of great value, and of immense and immeasurable possibilities—I have had the pleasure of knowing you for over a quarter of a cen
tury personally, and by name considerably longer—I remember your name coming into notice in 1876, in the early numbers of the "Bicycle News"—your name came then as the inventor of the safety bicycle—in these days, of course, it-was only a high bicycle, which 'it was more or les a gymnastic feat to ride—you were the first one who ever made the bicycle wide and secure in itself, and you founded in 1876 the safety bicycle, and introduced a machine which was improved in 1877, and was then ridden by the Hon. Robert Lowe, the Chan
cellor of the Exchequer—lam the author of a number of standard works on the cycle trade—I began writing them nearly 30 years ago, and. they are now the standard authorities in the cycle and motor trades—in-1879 you showed me your safety bicycle, the earlier safety of 1876 did not do, and in 1879 I called at Rudge's works at Coventry and jou showed me your invention, which was then quite new; that is the real introduction of the safety driving bicycles in the popular fornrof the present type of

machine—I remember your first company, the Rudge Cycle Company, being brought out; it was a great success and paid high dividends for several years—before it was brought out there was only a small paper syndicate with a few persons, Mr. Woodcock was one, with a very little capital, known as the Haynes and Jefferies Syndicate—in the early days it was not a success; it was very struggling in the Haynes and Jefferies period in 1875—companies which are sometimes only struggling in early days do not deserve to be smashed; they very often afterwards, in developing, become great successes. That invention afterwards filled Coventry with works, buildings and houses for workmen to such an extent that the casual ward of the workhouse had to be hired for workmen to sleep in—in 1896 there was no room for works or for workmen—all that sprang from the development of the safety bicycle of which you were the origi
nator in 1879—you started the motor industry, or patent, with the same company on September 27th 1880—that was the first application of an engine applied to cycles or motors—your invention in motors was the first petrol driven motor for traction purposes in this country'—at that time there were syndicates to bring out the company—I do not know anything about the percentage—I went down with a number of gentlemen and members of Parliament to take part in the opening of the first motor works in Coventry"; the works are going on now—the company which you formed has continued to the present time—thousands of British workmen are employed upon the industry which was started by companies and syndicates—I am the author of this pamphlet (Produced) and every statement in it is proved in black and white, references to patents and other data, to be true—the first Stanley Show was held in March at the Athenaeum, Camden Town, in 1872—in this photo
graph there is the first modern lady's bicycle patented in 1884—the drawing of that shows in the patent the impossibility of bicycles of that period as compared with the present time—the bicycle of 1876 was also adapted for ladies—there were some so-called ladies' bicycles, but they were impracticable—the Aeriel-Vincent could be ridden in ordinary clothes by lady riders, but it was both dangerous, and a great deal too high for a practical bicycle at all—you took part in the Lord Mayor's Show in 1896; this is a photo
graph of it; it is taken outside the Old Bailey—you were the instigator of the first great demonstration to Brighton on November 14th, 1896, which celebrated the freeing of the motor-car—you ran a Bill in Parlia
ment in conjunction with other gentlemen to free the motor-car from the Locomotives Act; that came into operation on November 14th. 1896.

Cross-examined. The motor wheel was a motor of great value. I believe, with great potentialities; it belongs to the Construction Company which is now considering an offer; they have power to deal with it; I have not examined the document giving the power—every development of every business depends upon the interests of others, the interest of the company everywhere, and every undertaking in the world depends upon that—I know something about the business and financial arrange
ments of the company—I consider the company is carrying out its

business—the directors have their own opinions, they are not entirely subordinate to the master man; but in a one-man industry the biggest shareholder would naturally have influence, end carry weight—I do not know Lawson's arrangements as to how he is to get money out of the company; a great deal would depend upon it—if Lawson spent money in carrying out the projects of the company and he comes to the company for the return of the money, and he pays for the work he has done in connection with the company, then he is entitled to it, whatever he asks in reason—if he does an amount of work that comes to £1,000. and he asks for £20,000 for it it would be out of reason—I should make a certain amount of enquiry into payments—if a man asked fur nearly £'20,000 without saying what it was for I would not pay it blindly—I should not approve of directors who agree to pay £20,000 without having any particulars.
By the COURT. The date of this pamphlet is this year.

Re-examined. I have had very many years' connection with various companies—I would not say the directors were dishonest because they took the advice of their engineers—if a man is advancing all the capital, and has introduced £350,000 to a company which has never done any
thing but on the advice of that man, I should not call it a—dishonest practice because he took his fees.

MR. MYNE. I am an accountant and work for Messrs. Morse and Co.—I have not been through the Construction Company's books, only inasmuch as certain receipts are concerned—my firm has got copies of your accounts from the books at the Treasury—I have not been to the Board of Trade and looked at the books, but one of my fellow clerks has—I have sent to your banks, the London and Westminster and Lloyds, and have got these accounts from them—I have got out these different items which you have paid through, your bank for Con
struction Company's work that do not appear in the Company's books.

FREDERICK DAVEY
Re-examined by the Solicitor General. I have now gone through, these receipts with a view to ascertaining how they stand as regards the Electric Construction Company—the first is dated September 29th, 1901: "Received from the Construction Company £1,000 on account of printing, &c, in connection with the Blackpool Tramway prospectus, £1,000," from Robinson's—I do not find in the books a direct payment from the Construction Company to the Robinson Printing Company, but on September 24th, 1901, there is a cheque of Lawson's of £1,000, and on September 29th the cheque is charged"to liawson's account—on this day he receives credit for £1,331 and Robin
son's Printing Company is debited with this sum in respect of cheques paid—I have credited Lawson with that amount in my summary—it seems to be a receipt in respect of the same payment that is already in the account—the next receipt is January 23rd, 1902:"Received from Lawson, Esq., the sum of £200, being payment on account of fees in the matter of the Llanelly Trams, &c—Bramwell & Harris"—I find that was paid to the Company, and charged to the proper account in the ledger—the next is February 6th, 1902: "Received from the Electric

Construction Company the sum of one hundred guineas, being a payment on account in respect of our foe of 1,000 guineas in the matter of the Nottingham and Derby Light Railway Companies and the Company"—the next is dated Aug.8th, 1902: "£1,000 received from the Electric Con
struction Company by Robinson on account of printing City and Surrey Prospectus"—I find that was paid by Lawson, according to his bank pass book, but I do not find that there was any obligation on the part of the Construction Company to pay anything in connection with the flotation of the City and Surrey Railway—my impression is that the National Electric Traction Company was to pay the expenses of the City and Surrey Railway—I find that Lawson received four cheques of £5,000 each from the Tramway Trust, which on the same day had been paid to the Trust by the National Electric Traction Company—that appears by the National Electric Traction Company's cash book, which is the only book I have—the next one is dated Sept-ember 18th, 1902: "Received from H.J. Lawson the sum of £31, being cost of preparing plans for the proposed North Lancashire Tramways, including the cost of lithography, also including the services rendered in connection 'ith the tramway extension to the Borough of Qssett"—I find that was paid by Lawson, but I do not find that the Construction Company had anything to do with the"North Lancashire scheme—there is no account in their books of the North Lancashiretrains—the next is dated October 12th: "The sum of £25 for services rendered in connection with the negotiations for the reduction of the charges of the professional men for their work on the Wakefield and District and the Mansfield and District Light Railway Orders"—I found that that was from Lawson—I do not find any trace of it in the books of the Construction Company—I find an account, but not this amount in the account—this document (Produced) is apparently a bill of costs. Harrison. Beaumont & Smith, and at the end of it is. "November (5th, 1902. This balance of £1,195 5s. 9d. agreed at £1,100 Two cheques, one for £250 to-day,"that is November (jth, "and one for £250. dated the 2."Jrd inst., paid on account."' and signed "Harrison. Beaumont & Smith,"' and underneath, "Approved for the Electric Traction Co., H.J. Lawson"—I have not been able to trace these two cheques for £250—I have looked at Lawson's pass book for that date—I do not find any cheques that would appear to show that he had made the payment—there is a receipt of February 9th for £50 to William Webb & Co., akefield and District Tramway."Received of the Electric Tramways Trust, Limited, the sum of £50, on account of out of pocket disburse
ments, payable under agreement of December 17, 1902"—I have no means of tracing the payment at all, because the Construction Company's books end at December, 1902, and I have not Lawson's pass book for that date.
Cross-examined by Lawson. I know that two of the £5000 cheques were paid—some moneys havo been paid by you which have not been entered in the books.
Lawson in his defence said thai the Construction Company had had a (jenuine business; that it still owned the Epstein and motor wheel 'patents,

besides orders or concessions for railways and tramways, the success of any one of which might s'ill brim the company into the first rank; thai he had had no money from Hooley in respect of any of Hooky's transactions with Paine, and Hooley had never had any connection ivith any of his Lawson's) companies; that he had had nothing to do with bringing Paine into the company; that when he heard thit Paine icas coming into the company, he was at first glad to hear of a man coming in who might be able to help the company's interests, but that afterwards he tried his hardest to get rid of him, and especially to get rid of am contract with Mrs. Hooley; that although he had transferred, shares which were not at the moment in existence, he submitted that teas a common practice in the share market, especially in regard to new companies; thai tne statements at the dinner in September, 1900, were what he honestly believed to be true; that he was not in the legal sense the manager of the company, although since the middle of 1902 he had been the practical manager of the company, he and Paine being the only holders of shares, and thai he was not guilty of the charges against him.

HOOLEY—
NOT GUILTY .

LAWSON—
GUILTY
on the eighth and following counts.
Twelve months' hard labour.

p.hi: agreed to state a case for Lawson upon the point as to whether although manager in fact, the section covers such a manager; the operation of the sentence to be postponed—until the case has been determined.

div1.p:
52.
HENRY JOHN LAWSON was again indicted for
that he being a member of the
Electric Tramways (Construction and Maintenance Company did unlawfully and fraudulently apply to his own use and benefit certain property of that company, and
ERNEST TERAH HOOLEY
with aiding and abetting Lawson to commit that misdemeanour.
THE SOLICITOR GENERAL for the prosecution offered no evidence against HOOLEY.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: No verdict was taken as to Lawson, who was admitted to bail.

div1.p:
53.
RALPH BERMEL (46) and
CLARA BERMEL (19)
, Stealing ls., the moneys of
Julia Bristow.

HERBERT BUCKINGHAM . I am manager to Mrs. Julia Bristow, the licensee of the George, Stratford—on October 25th I advertised for a barmaid—the prisoner, Clara Bermel, came and said her name was Jeffreys—I asked her where she had been, and she said at the Pigeons, Romford Road, for ten months—I said, "If your reference is satisfactory I will wire to you and pay for the reply"—I then went to Mr. Frost' to inquire about Miss Jeffreys, and next day received a communication from him—on the 26th I engaged the female prisoner as barmaid, and she came on duty—on the 28th I received a

further communication from"Frost, and afterwards saw him—on my return to the George I kept a watch on the female prisoner—on Saturday, October 21th, I saw her on four different occasions pass money to the male prisoner—first, he gave twopence over the bar to her, and received a handful of coppers in exchange—the second iime he placed three halfpence on the counter, and received a handful of coppers—on the third and fourth occasions the same thing occurred—I was close behind the female prisoner—these things took place between 7 "30 and 8 p.m.—in consequence of wjiat I saw I communicated with the police, and Scrimshaw and Bailey came into the side bar—I walked to the further end of the bar, and returned to the office—I think 15s. to £1 must have been passed over the bar.

Cross-examined. We use Fox's till—the silver is kept at the side—it is registered if it is put in the till—we count the coppers occasionally, but we can tell about what amount there ought to be—we were very busy when the male prisoner was in the bar—about twenty people were there—the male prisoner called for drinks—he was near the counter—the female prisoner put the coppers into his hand from her closed fist—I was about two feet away—she took as many coppers as her hand would hold—I allowed them to repeat the operation four times without saying a word to her.

JOHN FROST . I am a licensed victualler, and keep the Pigeons public house, Romford Road—my barmaid Jeffreys left me on Saturday, October 23 th—the female prisoner is not that barmaid, but she was a barmaid at my public house—I did not give her notice—she was discharged on Saturday, October 22nd—Jeffreys had served me three years in two terms—there is no suggestion against her character, but the very opposite—I received a communication as to the character of a barmaid calling herself Jeff revs, and thinking it was my late barmaid I gave her a character—in consequence of a further communication I received from Buckingham I sent for him and saw him.

GEORGE SCRIMSHAW
Detectice-Sergeant). In consequence of infor
mation, I went to the George on Saturday, October 29th, about 9 p.m.—in the public bar I saw the male prisoner and the female prisoner behind the bar, serving—I stood behind the male prisoner who was standing between the hot water urn and a pillar—he put H-d. on the counter, and said to the female prisoner, "Mild and Burton, Miss, please"—in a few seconds she served him—she took the Hd. to the till, put her hand in the bowl, came back to the male prisoner and said, "your change, Sir"—he opened his hand—I looked over his shoulder—I saw 6d. In silver and—1d. In bronze—a few minutes later I asked for a drink, and could not get one—I said to Bailey in the hearing of the prisoner, "We will go somewhere else"—the male prisoner said, "Blind me. I have been waiting a long time, and cannot get served myself"—a few minutes later the manager walked very slowly to the other end of the bar, and returned—the male prisoner looked at him and while he was away, said to the female prisoner, "It is all right, he is down at the

bottom now"—she served other customers, then went to the till, took out a handful of something, came to the male prisoner, and said, "Your change, Sir"—he opened his hand, and as he received it I caught it—he said, "You cannot have my change"—I said, "Yes, and you too: we are police, and shall take you to the police station"—two other chaps rushed out of the bar—the prisoner became violent, but we eventually got him out into the lobby—just outside the station he said, "It is no use, I can see you have got me properly, I am very sorry"—He was conveyed to the police station—on being searched, sixpence and threepence was found in his right hand trousers pocket; in his left hand pocket is. 9d., all in bronze—I made an examination of his trousers, and I find that there is a cut in them so that you can inssrt your hand into the pocket and drop anything down the trouser leg—he was detained at the station, and I went back to the house and told the female prisoner about her father, and that I was going to arrest her—she said, "It is quite right, I gave the money to my father, he has been out of work for months; our family is starving, or I should not have done, it"—I accompanied her to get her dress; she threw her arms round my neck and said, "I am sorry, do not lock me up"—when charged, she made no reply—later I made an examination of the chests of drawers of each of the barmaids, and turned out some wearing apparel—one skirt in the prisoner's drawer had a slit in front, under where the apron comes, so that she could put her hand, under the pretence of getting a handkerchief, into the pocket of this pouch Produced) where anything could be dropped in.

Cross-examined. I first got to the public house at 9-15 p.m.—they were very busy there—a good many people were standing at the bar—they could not all see what the male prisoner was doing—he was between a pillar and the urn on the counter—he did no!; put sixpence on the counter—the second time he called for a mild and Burton and did not put anything down—he did not put down a shilling the third time—he did not call for cigarettes—he did not put down a shilling for Woodbines—an old gentleman next to the prisoner did not call for three halves of whisk)' hot, and put. bwn a two shilling piece—the male prisoner dii not say, "No, that won't do"—the other people in the bar appeared to be looking after themselves—no money was put on the counter, except one three half-pence, from beginning to end—some few coppers fell on the ground, and I had some red hot in his hand—he did not say, 'I have not passed bad money,"nor, "It is all right, and you need'not look at it'—the female prisoner only said, "That is your change, Sir"—the following morning I asked her if she wanted to send to her friends, or wished me to make enquiries—I did not tell her that it would be better to make a clean breast of it, and that that was the best thing for her to do—she did not say, "I won't do any
thing of the kind; I have nothing to be ashamed of"—an officer would not be allowed to advise a prisoner.
JOHN BAILEY (5 K.). On October 29th I went to the George public

house with Scrimshaw—I saw the female prisoner behind the bar—I stood in the public bar close to the male prisoner—I was in plain clothes—he wts leaning on the counter almost opposite the hot water apparatus—he called for beer, was served by Clara and put Hd. down in payment—Clara went away a second, came back, said, "Your change, Sir,"and dropped sixpence and some bronze into the male prisoner's hand—he put it into his right hip pocket—Buckingham walked to the other end of the bar, and when Clara came up to the male prisoner, he said, "He Is at the other end of the bar"—Clara went away a few seconds, then came back and said, "Your change, Sir,"and dropped something in Ralph's hand—he had not called for a drink that time—Scrimshaw seized Ralph's hand, while I seized the other arm: we struggled—Ralph sad, "You cannot have my change,"—I said, "We will have your change and you as well"—some coppers fell on to the floor—we got him out of the house after a struggle and took him to the station—on the way he said, "It is no good, you have got me fair."

Cross-examined. I made no note—Ralph did not call for cigarettes—I called for a cigar—nobody called for cigarettes—I do not remember anybody putting down two shillings on the bar for whiskies—Ralph did not say when we took him out of the house, "The shilling was a good shilling"—he did not complain on the road to the station that he was wrongly arrested for passing bad money—he did not say to his daughter, "It is all right, you need not look at it, it is good, though it is thin"—I did not hear that the house was very full—I saw him pass no more money than the lid.—I was eight or ten inches from the hot water apparatus, and he was standing between the column and the urn—Scrimshaw was on his right—I was between the two—other people were round—some of them I knew.

The prisoner in his defence on oath said, that he came into the neighbourhood to look for a business as a butcher, that at West Ham Police Station he had 5s. 1d., but in the public house he had 1s., 5 sixpences, and 3s. 1d. In coppers, rolled up in a packet, which he had taken from his boifs money box, and the coppers came from the packet, that he put down 6d. and his daughter gave him 442. change, that he tendered 1s. and received 11d. change, and that he only received his proper change while he ivas there.
GUILTY .

p.hi:
was recommended to leniency on account of her youth, her father's influence, and her previous good character. Mr. Frost slated tliat he had discharged her for a similar offence.
Three months' hard labour.

div1.p:
RALPH BURMEL—
Twelve months' hard labour.

54.
WILLIAM JOHNSON (42)
PLEADED GUILTY
to stealing 2s. from
Lilian Marie Simpson, the moneys of
Frederick Simpson; having been convicted of felony at St. Mary's, Stoke Newington, on January 14th, 1003, ai
James Fry.
Several previous convictions were proved against him.
Three years' penal servitude.

55.
MAURICE BROWN (23) and
PATRICK BRESNAHAN (31)
, Feloniously assaulting
Adeline Ann Dannatt, with intent to rob her.
MR. PAVEY Prosecuted; MR. FORREST FULTON Defenled BRESNAHAN.

THOMAS CARTER . I am a labourer, of 1, Church Passage, Greenwich—on Monday, October 17th, about 10.30 a.m. I saw Brawn standing by the corner of the Eight Bells jmblie-nouse and
Chuich Passage for three' quarters of an hour, or a little longer,—till some time after eleven o'clock—I know him well—I have seen him several times—I said at the Police Court, "I have seen Brown at the Eight Bells three or four times a week."
Cross-examined by Brown. I did not see you do anything.

ADELINE ANN DANNATT . I am the wife of Walter Dannatt, and live at 75, Vanbrug Park, Blackheath—on October 17th I was in Church Passage, Greenwich, between 11.45 and 12 a.m., collecting for the Provident Club, which I always do on a Monday—I was carrying. this small handbag, which contained 8s. 8d., as I have it now on my left arm—I went to No.1, Church Passage, to collect—I had called and received nothing for the club, and was crossing over when I saw a man who was drunk, and crossed the passage to pass him—I was going to Church Street through Roan Street, and was within forty yards of Church Street—I saw a man running towards me from the direction of Church Street—I moved to the right to let him pass—as he came near me he half swerved round me and struck me in the face with his fist—I fell backwards to the ground—I do not remember any more except that I screamed—I must have become insensible, because I do not remember the action of falling—I got a good view of Brown, because I moved to let him pas", me—he is the furthest prisoner from me in the dock—after I had recovered from my dazed state, which was momentary., he was still running towards the Recreation Gates, and away from me—I could not get up, I got up a little way, and then some people came, from the cottages and helped me up—nothing was missing—I was injured from the blow in my face and from the fall, and the shock, my arms were grazed, and my left arm was cut a little—when I got to a cottage there were finger-marks on my arm.

Cross-examined by Brown. At the station I recognised you in my mind, but I was afraid to say so, because of the case of Adolph Beck, and you were much cleaner then—I did go up and down the row of men twice—I do not think I said anything at all—I had no private conver
sation with Inspector Hailstone except that he asked my name and address, and that kind of thing.
ARTHUR HAILSTONR (Inspector R). Mrs. Dannatt did not identify any of the prisoners on October 20th—Brown was placed with nine others, as near as possibly like him in dress and appearance.
MARY ANN CARTER . I am the wife of Samuel Carter, and live in

Church Passage, Greenwich—on Monday, October 17th, Mrs. Dannatt called upon me in the usual way, between 11 and 12 am., for my sub
scription—she had a bag on her arm—when she left she went towards Church Street—I had said good morning, and when she had got about five or six yards from my door I heard a blow—I had not got further indoors than the sill of the door when I heard a scream, and turned my head and saw Mrs. Dannatt lying on the ground—I got her up, and with the assistance of the neighbours brought her into my house, and bathed her face with warm water—I saw a man running by, but could not swear to him; I was looking after Mrs. Dannatt—he ran as hard as he could go—Mrs. Dannatt had a black eye, a cut across her nose, and was bleeding very much.

MARY ANN DAWES . I live at Greenwich—on October 17th I was in Church Passage about 11.45 to 11.50 a.m., when I heard someone call "Stop him, stop him"—Brown was running towards me—when he got close to me he looked at me and said, "You do, and I will serve you the same"—he meant if I stopped him—he ran past to Roan Street—he was a stranger—I saw Mrs. Dannatt on the ground—on October 20th I picked out Brown at Greenwich Police Court in the yard from 11 or 12 men in a row—I recognised him at once—I said, "That is the man."
Cross-examined by Brown. I was close to you—you had not so much beard as you have now.

WILLIAM BENNETT . I live at Roan Street, Greenwich, opposite Church Passage—I was in Roan Street, about midday, near the corner—I saw two men running down Roan Street—Brown was one of them—I recognised him as a chap I had seen standing about—I only know him as Brown—I saw thorn run round the corner—both the prisoners passed me—Brown was last, about twenty yards behind the other—on October 20 I picked out Brown from about a dozen men—I told the police I knew the man Brown.

ARTHUR WELLS . I am a carman, and lived at Eaton Street, Deptford, but I have moved now—on October 17th I was in Roan Street, just before twelve—I saw three men running from the direction'of Church Passage—the prisoners were two—they came within a yard of me—Bresnahan was leading, the second man I cannot recognise, and Brown was about a hundred yards behind—I had never seen them before—on October 20th, at the Greenwich Police Court yard, I picked them out from nine or ten men at once.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. The first time I saw Bresnahan was in Roan Street.

ARTHUR HAILSTONE (Re-examined.) On October 19th I arrested Brown at 10.20 p.m. at High Street, Deptford—I said, "Is your name Maurice Brown?"—He said "Yes.—I said, "I am a police inspector, and I am going to take you into custody for assaulting a lady in Church Passage on Monday morning" He said, "Is that all?" I said, "No, you will be placed with others for identification, and if identified you will be charged with assaulting a lady and attempting to rob her."I took him to Blackheath Police Station—when there he said, 'I was in Deptford all

Monday morning."—I said, "Very well, tell me where you were, and I will make enquiries"—subsequently he said, "Boo Jones, who works at the railway arches, Greenwich Street, is like me; I want you to have him here; he is the very image of me"—on the morning of October 20th he was placed with nine other men, and immediately identified by Dawes and Bennett—this is the first time to-day that I have heard Bennett say that he recognised Brown as the man he had seen hanging about the corner—I arrested Bresnahan about 10 p.m. on October 26th, at 6, Queen Street Deptford, in bed in a back room—I said to him, "Come on, Patsey"—I knew him—I said, "I am an inspector of police, and I am going to take you to Blackheath Station for assaulting a lady, with Maurice Brown, and attempting to rob her"—he said, "I was with Hoppy Day on all last Monday"—I took him to the station—he repeated that statement at the station—I said, "I have said nothing about Monday yet"—he said, "Last Monday week"—he was p'aced with others the same day as nearly like him in dress and appearance as we could find, and he was identified by Wells—he said nothing when charged—Mrs. Dannatt at the identification was very nervous, and said something about being afraid Dawes first described Brown as about her age and height and as a man of Italian appearance.

WILLIAM JONES . I am a labourer, of Deptford—I am known as Boo Jones—on Monday, October 17th, I was not in Greenwich—I know Brown as walking up and down the street—I am said to be like him—I do not know whether I am or not—I know nothing of this crime.
MICHAEL DAY . I am a labourer, of 12, Queen Street, Deptford—I am known as Hoppy Day—I know Bresnahan—on Monday, October 17th, I was not with him—I was out selling bundle-wood.
Cross-examined by MR. FULTON. I am not mistaken about the day—I have knocked about with Bresnahan—when I am doing nothing I see him.

p.hi: Brown in his defence said that he was not there, and that it was a mistake.

div1.p: GUILTY .

BRESNAHAN—
NOT GUILTY . Four other convictions were proved against Brown, and it was stated that he was an associate of thieves.
Eighteen months' hard labour.

56.
MARY ENTWISTLE (20)
PLEADED GUILTY
to unlawfully en
deavouring to conceal the birth of her female child by the secret disposition of its dead body.
Two days' imprisonment.

57.
THOMAS THOMPSON (20)
, Unlawfully by night being found with housebreaking implements in his possession.
ALFRED CRUTCHETT (Sergeant R). I was on duty, about 5.15 a.m., in Evelyn Street, Deptford, in company with Detective Pitta way on October 29th, when I saw the prisoner come out of the doorway of a

draper's shop—we thought it suspicious, so we kept him under observation—we crossed tho road, and, looking along the line of shops, saw him stoop down, apparently by a doorway, and strike a light—he then crossed over the road and went to a shop close to where he came from and struck another match—he went some distance towards Tower Bridge, and there we lost sight of him—we went in that direction, but were unable to find him, and we came back again—we then saw him standing at the street corner where we had first seen him—we had kept him under observation for half an hour—we went up to him and I said, "What are you waiting about here for?" he said, "I am waiting for my mate"; I said, "Where are you going when your mate comes?" he said, "I am going to "work, I mean we are going to look for some"; I said, "Where are you going?" he said, "Over the water"; I said, "Where is your mate coming from?" he said, "From over the water"; I said, "What is his name?" he made no reply and twisted about—I said, "What have you got about you?" and I put my hand on the outside of his jacket and felt something—he said, "That is my spectacle case," and took out a spectacle case—I touched his right hand jacket pocket, and he said, "That is a piece of bread, Sir," and he put his hand in his pocket and brought out a piece of bread—I took hold of his hand and found underneath the bread this bag containing four keys and this piece of candle (Produced)—I said,' I shall take you to the station"and I did so—at the station I searched him and found four skeleton keys, two in his right hand waistcoat pocket and two in his left; there were eight keys altogether with those that were in the bag—I also found this small jemmy (Produced), which would be used for forcing a drawer, these two pieces of wire, which might be used for picking a lock (Produced), and this box of matches (Produced)—the prisoner said, "I picked them up in the gutter as I was coming over Tower Bridge; I saw it lying in the gutter; I kicked it and it sounded all right; I thought it was money so I picked it up and put it in my pocket"—he was speaking of the bag of keys—after making certain enquiries, I went to 48, Hough ton Koad, Bow, where I found in the room which he occupied this jemmy, and this piece of wire (Produced)—I showed them to him after
wards, and he said, "That piere of wire I use for cleaning anything; the chisekis mine, you can see where I have hammered it on the head. "

By the COURT. I only saw him go into one door—I could not see him try any doors—when he struck the matches, I take it he was looking at the keyhole; he stooped down to the level of the keyhole—he was smoking at the time, so he could not have struck the matches to light his pipe—it was quite dark at the time.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I picked them up in the gutter, as I have said, and these pieces of wire are merely pipe cleaners; this policeman did not see me do anything."

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence said, that while going across Tower Bridge he saw a bag in the gutter, that he kicked it, and as it sounded all right he picked it up, and found it contained keys: that he had had a good mind to throw it over the bridge, but resolved to keep it until he saw the man to

whom he was going for a job; (hat lie was trying to light his pipe when the constable saiv him strike the matches; that he also picked up the jemmy on the bridge, which had probably fallen off a country cart, being used to extract stones from horses' hoofs; that he used the pieces of wire as pipe cleaners, and that the candle never belonged to him.

div1.p:
GUILTY .— One previous conviction ivas proved against him.
Six months' hard labour.

58.
OLIVER KINGSLEY (34),
PLEADED GUILTY
to the manslaughter of
Eliza Jane Williams.
He received an excellent character.
Six months' hard labour.

59.
HENRY PAYS (19) and
WILLIAM JONES (24)
(who is deaf and dumb), committing an unnatural crime with each other.

PAYS
PLEADED GUILTY .
MR. ELLIOTT and MR. FITCH Prosecuted.

During the evidence the Court considered that Jones should be tried as to whether he was fit to plead to the indictment. The Jury were therefore discharged from giving a verdict, and were again sworn to try as to whether the prisoner could plead.
On the evidence of Dr. James Scott, the medical officer at Brizton Prison, they found that the prisoner was not in a condition to give proper instructions for his defence or to defend himself.
To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure.
PAYS, against whom a former conviction was proved.
Three years' penal servitude.

60.
ERNEST DE PICK (30)
PLEADED GUILTY
in incurring debts and liabilities to
Robert Frederick Mosely to the amount of £40 10s., and to
W. Johnson, Limited, to the amount of £255 2s. 6d., did in each case obtain credit under false pretences.
Judgment respited. (See next case.)

61.
ERNEST DE PICK was again indicted
for feloniously stealing a diamond and emerald cluster ring and a bracelet, the goods of
Frederick Iosley.
NOT GUILTY .

62.
JOHN DAVID HOOPER,
Unlawfully obtaining oredit from
Albert Charles to the extent of £26 10s. without informing him he was an undischarged bankrupt.
MR. LEYCESTER Prosecuted; Mr. Hutton Defended.
ALBERT CHARLES I am a dealer in jewellery, living at Keldon Road, Clapham Common—I have no shop—I first knew the prisoner

about a fortnight before October 13th—on that day I mot him at the Horns public house, Kennington—I showed him some jewellery: amongst other things three rings and a pair of earrings—he said he thought he could dispose of them; if I would let him have them he would see me at 8 o'clock at Charing Cross Hal way station and either give me the mo tiev or the goods—£8 10s. was my price for one ring £100 10s. for another ring, £3 10s. for another, and £8 for the earrings; £2l. 10s. altogether—I let him have the goods—I went at.5 o'clock to Charing Cross station, and waited till l. 20: but I did not see him again at all—he had given his address as 21, Ofilev Road, Kennington—I went there next morning—I did not sec him there—I was told he would be there shortly—I did not succeed in meeting him till I saw him at the Police Court—he never informed me that he was an undischarged bankrupt—I discovered that, a few days before I consulted my solicitor—on October 25th, I swore an information, and obtained a summons—I have not ascertained what has become of the jewellery.
(Cross-examination postponed at Mr. Hutton request).

GEORGE INGLIS BOYLE . I am a messenger in the. Bankruptcy Division of the High Court of Justice—I produce the file in the bank
ruptcy of the prisoner, in the name of John David Hooper—he is described as & licensed victualler—the receiving order and adjudication were made on February 3rd. 8W—he has never obtained his discharge. There being no evidence, that the prisoner teas the bankrupt, the Court directed the Jury to find a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

63.
GORDON LENNOX MORRISON (34)
, Forging and uttering an order for the payment of £1 4s., with intent to defraud.

GEORGE ALFONSO SPOOXER . I am a reservist, and entitled to reserve pay—I lived recently at Rowton House, Newington Butts—I expected 24s. on October 3rd—I did not authorise anybody to receive) it—this is no my signature—I did not authorise anyone to sign this receipt.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I was discharged with ignomy in consequence of being concerned in felonies—I was arrested on October 13th for endeavouring to steal a coat from St. George's Hospital—I was not in possession of a bag having £10 in it.
Re-examined. I first became aware that the order had been cashed after I wrote to the manager of Powton House to take it for me as I was in prison, and he replied to me.

HENRY WATERS . I am a booking, clerk at Rowton House, Newington Batts—I do not know Spooner—I received letters for a man named Spooner, which called to my mind that a man of that name on the night of October 3rd had asked to book a bed, and I recognise that man as the prisoner—I handed him the letters—on October 31st he gave the name of
Spoonor when applying for a bed—when I taxed him with obtaining the letters he said that he belonged to the Aimy Medical Corps.

HERBERT NELL . I am a clerk in the Army Pay Office—I issued this money order on October 3rd—it is payable to G.A. Spooner, and is addressed to Rowton House—an identity certificate was posted at the same time in a separate envelope—it was returned the next day through the post office.

HERBERT JOHN COOPER . I am a clerk in the Parliament Street Post Office—this money order was presented to me on October 4th—the identity certificate was presented at the same time—the order is for £1 4s., and is properly signed—I cannot recognise to whom I paid it.

FRANK PIKE
Detective L.). On October 31st I found the prisoner detained at Rowton House, Newington Butts—I told him I should arrest him for forging and uttering a money order for a reservist named Spooner—he said, "All right,"—I conveyed him to the police station—in the presence of the Inspector he said;"This is how it happened; Spooner and I were out for a walk together; outside St. George's hospital he asked me to wait; a few minutes afterwards a policeman brought him out, and he was taken to Gerrard Road Police Station; the following morning I endorsed the order in his name; he asked me twice."

p.hi: The prisoner, in his defence on oath, said the prosecutor had been about with him at his expense, and had asked him to get the money, and had given him two letters and the identity certificate, and the next morning after the prosecutor was taken into custody he cashed the order at Parliament Street Post Office.

div1.p: GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, DECEMBER 12TH, 1904.
